Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. Today's call will include prepared remarks by Scott McGregor, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Eric Brandt, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
This call will include forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause Broadcom's results to differ materially and adversely from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the cautionary statements and risk factors contained in the earnings release, which was furnished with the SEC today, and is available on our website and in our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent reports on Form 10-Q. We undertake no obligation to revise or update publicly any forward-looking statement to reflect future events or circumstances.
Additionally, throughout this call, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Today's earnings and the related current report on Form 8-K describe the differences between our non-GAAP and GAAP reporting and present a reconciliation between the 2 for the periods reported in the release. Please also see the Investors section of our website at investors.broadcom.com for a slide deck that includes additional information disclosed in accordance with SEC Regulation G.
It is now my pleasure to introduce Broadcom's President and Chief Executive Officer, Scott McGregor.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thanks for joining us. Broadcom had strong results in the December quarter. Revenue was at the high end of the guided range and non-GAAP EPS for the quarter came in ahead of First Call consensus. In the Broadband and Connectivity segme
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thanks for joining us. Broadcom had strong results in the December quarter. Revenue was at the high end of the guided range and non-GAAP EPS for the quarter came in ahead of First Call consensus. In the Broadband and Connectivity segment, revenues declined less than we initially expected. In broadband access, there is significant operator interest to upgrade last-mile access technologies such as DSL and PON to the fastest speeds. In set-top box, developed markets are upgrading to new media server architectures, and we're starting to see the first UltraHD boxes roll out. The decline in connectivity was also more modest than we initially expected due to the success of new phone launches, as well as increasing penetration of 802.11ac and 2x2 solutions. In infrastructure, our business declined as expected due to lower data center and service provider spending. For 2014, we delivered record revenues and record reportable segment profitability. Our BCG and ING revenue grew 6% while operating profit grew 25%, consistent with our goal of profitable growth.
I'll go into these items in more detail later in the call. But first, I'll turn the call over to Eric for details on the fourth quarter results and on first quarter guidance.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. As Peter mentioned, please refer to the data breakout on the Investors section of our website for additional introduction that will supplement my financial commentary. As previously discussed at our Analyst Day, we are now including stock-b
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. As Peter mentioned, please refer to the data breakout on the Investors section of our website for additional introduction that will supplement my financial commentary. As previously discussed at our Analyst Day, we are now including stock-based compensation in our non-GAAP operating results in addition to allocating it to our reportable segments. We decided to make this change to recognize/reflect all employee costs in our results and align with many investors' financial models. Consistent with this, we have recast our segments and other non-GAAP financial information in our 10-K and web financial statements for the current and prior periods. For the purposes of comparability with external estimates and prior guidance, we are also providing the comparable non-GAAP metrics excluding stock-based compensation in the following discussion. Going forward, we will guide gross margin and R&D and SG&A expenses that includes stock-based compensation.
Moving to the financial overview. To summarize, Q4 revenue came in at $2.14 billion, down 5.2% sequentially and up 3.8% year-over-year. Excluding cellular baseband revenue, reportable segment revenue was down 3% sequentially and up 10% year-over-year. Q4 non-GAAP gross margin was up 60 basis points from Q3 to 54.7%. Our Q4 non-GAAP gross margin now includes roughly 30 basis points of stock-based compensation. Q4 GAAP gross margin was 52.8%. Q4 R&D plus SG&A expenses were down $46 million, including stock-based compensation. Q4 non-GAAP EPS excluding stock-based compensation was $0.90 a share or $0.03 above First Call consensus of $0.87 per share. Including stock-based compensation, Q4 non-GAAP EPS was $0.76 a share. Q4 GAAP EPS was $0.64 a share, which includes $0.09 of additional impairment and restructuring charges principally related to our exit of the cellular baseband business. Cash flow from operations for Q4 was $633 million. Our cash and marketable securities balance at the end of the quarter was $6 billion.
Moving to revenue and gross margin. In December, we updated our guided range for Q4 revenue to between $2.075 billion and $2.15 billion. We delivered revenue right at the high end of that range at $2.143 billion. Our Broadband and Connectivity revenue came in ahead of expectations at $1.48 billion, down roughly 2% sequentially. Upside in the quarter was in wireless connectivity and broadband modems. Revenue from our Infrastructure & Networking segment met our expectations of down sequentially at $625 million. Q4 non-GAAP gross margin was up 60 basis points from Q3 to 54.7% and includes roughly 30 basis points of stock-based compensation. This was at the midpoint of our guided range of 55% excluding stock-based compensation. Q4 GAAP gross margin was up from Q3 to 52.8%.
Moving to operating expenses. Total R&D and SG&A expenses were slightly above our revised guidance in December and down $46 million from Q3 levels, including stock-based compensation as a couple of unplanned tape-outs occurred late in the quarter. Going forward, non-GAAP and GAAP R&D plus SG&A should be the same and will be consolidated into a single estimate.
Moving to the balance sheet. Cash and marketable securities ended Q4 at $6 billion, of which 48% is in the U.S. Cash flow from operations was $633 million. During the quarter, we paid $72 million in dividends and repurchased 2.5 million shares of stock at a cost of $104 million. We announced an increase in our quarterly dividend by 17% to $0.14 per share. We also continue to target repurchasing $1 billion of stock in 2015. Q4 accounts receivable day sales outstanding were 34 days and net inventory turns were 7.6.
Moving to restructuring and impairment charges. In Q4, we recorded restructuring cost of $16 million and impairment charges of $14 million as we continue to exit our wind-down of our cellular baseband business. We expect to record an additional $40 million of restructuring charges over the next 12 months, primarily related to the closing or consolidation of 19 locations.
Moving to expectations. We currently expect net revenue in Q1 to be $2 billion, plus or minus $75 million. From a segment perspective, we expect Broadband and Connectivity to be down and Infrastructure & Networking to be roughly flat. We expect Q1 non-GAAP gross margin to be roughly flat to Q4 at 54.7%, plus or minus 75 basis points. And GAAP gross margin to be flat as well at 52.8%, plus or minus 75 basis points. We expect R&D and SG&A expenses in Q1 to be up between $5 million and $25 million, which again now includes stock-based compensation.
And now I'd like to turn the call back over to Scott to talk more about the state of the business.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. Starting with the Broadband and Connectivity business, our revenue came in at $1.475 billion, down roughly 2% sequentially and better than we initially expected. Upside in the quarter was across the board, including set-top box, broadband ac
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. Starting with the Broadband and Connectivity business, our revenue came in at $1.475 billion, down roughly 2% sequentially and better than we initially expected. Upside in the quarter was across the board, including set-top box, broadband access and particularly wireless connectivity.
In set-top box, we're seeing growth in emerging markets and new technologies. Operators such as DISH in North America, Free in France and Tata in India have begun to offer UltraHD set-top boxes to their subscribers. We're expecting at least 15 operators across multiple regions to launch 4K television service in 2015.
In broadband access, the race to gigabit speeds in the home continues as telcos invest in G.fast and cable MSOs invest in DOCSIS 3.1, while both invest in high-speed optical access. Broadcom is leading this transition with our first design wins with G.fast and 10-gig EPON already in place.
In connectivity, we saw increased demand for newly introduced smartphones combined with increasing adoption of new wireless technologies such as 802.11ac and 2x2 solutions that drive higher ASPs. 5G WiFi revenues reached a record high in the quarter and more than doubled for the year. We're seeing significant customer interest in our 4x4 multiuser MIMO 5G WiFi chip, targeted for retail routers, broadband access gateways and set-top boxes. In addition, we're broadening our connectivity business beyond smartphones into adjacent markets. For example, we are powering both Denon and Harman Kardon's WiFi home audio systems. We've also received our first design win for our wireless charging solution.
We continue to diversify into new markets such as Internet of Things, automotive, wearables and small cells. In the Internet of Things market, design activity remains high with our current products, and we're in the process of refreshing our portfolio with purpose-built products that are optimized specifically for different market segments. Registrations for our WICED Internet of Things platform have grown dramatically, from 2,000 at the beginning of 2014 to over 8,000 now. We announced the expansion of our distribution channel with more than 40 new partners to expand our sales reach to Internet of Things customers.
Lastly, small cell remains an emerging opportunity. We're ramping our newly launched LTE and TD-SCDMA solutions while maintaining our market-leading position in 3G. We're starting to see increasing adoption from carriers. For example, we're working with SpiderCloud, who recently announced they'll be supplying Verizon for 4G enterprise small cells. Looking into Q1, we expect our Broadband and Connectivity business to be down sequentially.
Moving to infrastructure. Our Infrastructure & Networking Group declined as expected, down 4% sequentially to $625 million. The data center segment was relatively stronger than the enterprise and service provider segments. In the data center market, we have a large number of customers in production with Trident II and are building a solid pipeline of design wins for Tomahawk. At 3.2 terabits per second, Tomahawk is the industry's highest bandwidth switching solution and has been shipped to over 15 different networking box makers, establishing an early lead over competitors. Longer term, we remain confident in growth drivers that include new buildouts and expansions of data centers, increasing data traffic and faster speeds and ASIC conversions to merchant solutions.
In the service provider market, we're seeing broad adoption of our 28-nanometer heterogenous knowledge-based processors. We also delivered version 2.0 of our OpenFlow SDN or software-defined networking reference platform that delivers on the flexibility and control requirements for large scale carrier network deployments.
Finally, we released an enhanced version of our BroadR-Reach ethernet product that extends our automotive market opportunity beyond infotainment and driver assistance into telematics, satellite antennas and instrumentation clusters. We currently have design wins with 5 automakers and expect solid growth this year. As we look into Q1, we expect our Infrastructure & Networking business to be roughly flat sequentially.
In summary, our Broadband and Connectivity and our Infrastructure & Networking segments performed well during the fourth quarter, and we exceeded our expectations for both revenue and operating profits. 2014 has been the third consecutive year of double-digit growth for our Infrastructure & Networking business due to our leadership in the switch market. Broadband and Connectivity saw single-digit growth in 2014 due to a strong position in the high end of the phone market and set-top box and access markets.
This concludes our prepared comments, and we're now ready for your questions. Lakeba, may we have the first question please.

componenttext: And good execution on the cash generation side in Q4. When I look at the Q1 outlook implied for the Broadband and Connectivity segment, it was sales down about 8%. Not that far off from the down 6%, 7% in prior years. Do you think, Scott, this business is back to seasonal trends, i.e., the connectivity part has stabilized? Or do you still think there are some shoes to sort of drop on the connectivity side, so it could take somewhat longer to get back to more seasonal trends?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think our connectivity business is strong. We've had very good strength in the high end of the market, continue to do so. We've been able to migrate our customers to higher-end solutions, including 802.11ac and moving towards 2x2. Not all of our custome
componenttext: I think our connectivity business is strong. We've had very good strength in the high end of the market, continue to do so. We've been able to migrate our customers to higher-end solutions, including 802.11ac and moving towards 2x2. Not all of our customers have moved to 2x2, so there's some opportunity to move there, and we see other technologies becoming available as well. We're also broadening our technology portfolio in connectivity to include things like wireless charging and other technologies. So we see that business over the long term. I think this year will be potentially a little challenging. But over the long term, we see that as a growth business. In terms of seasonality, a little hard to predict there because it tends to be affected by the inventory and the consumption of some of our larger customers. But again, that's a real good business, I think, going forward.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then as my follow-up on the Infrastructure & Networking business, it has been doing well for a long period of time. But when I look at Q4 and Q1, the implied growth rate is about 5% to 6% year-on-year, and I think you had mentioned some good t
componenttext: Got it. And then as my follow-up on the Infrastructure & Networking business, it has been doing well for a long period of time. But when I look at Q4 and Q1, the implied growth rate is about 5% to 6% year-on-year, and I think you had mentioned some good trends on the data center side, but slow down on the carrier side. When do you see that business get back to your target sort of double-digit growth rate? And what's going to be the catalyst? Is it new products? Does China LTE spending need to turn back up? When will we start to see your traditional growth trajectory in that business?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our infrastructure business is driven by a number of factors. They include, certainly, capital spending on the part of the large carriers. It includes the buildouts of large data centers and then the overall enterprise upgrade as people move to higher spe
componenttext: Our infrastructure business is driven by a number of factors. They include, certainly, capital spending on the part of the large carriers. It includes the buildouts of large data centers and then the overall enterprise upgrade as people move to higher speeds. We also introduced a number of new products and continue to push forward there. So all of those are the factors that drive growth, and many of those we don't control. But over the longer term, we do see that as a double-digit business. And what it works out to exactly this year, again, will depend on those factors, and it's hard for us to predict. But certainly, we see that as a double-digit growth business over a multiple year period.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: One quick one for Eric. In Q4, the buyback, I believe, was about $100 million, but I think you allocated $1 billion this year. Should we expect that to be spread sort of evenly across all the quarters or more front end or back-end loaded?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say, it really does depend on the stock price. But I would say, our intention is to be more or less evenly distributed across the quarters, maybe a little bit more front end, depends on how the market's behaving.
componenttext: I would say, it really does depend on the stock price. But I would say, our intention is to be more or less evenly distributed across the quarters, maybe a little bit more front end, depends on how the market's behaving.

componenttext: Within Broadband and Connectivity and specifically, I'm more focused on broadband on the Q1 guide, is this primarily seasonal declines? And then as you think primarily about 2015, what's the confidence level about driving growth in the broadband segment? And maybe some color on what products and end markets are going to be driving that growth? Is it going to be more set-top box driven or more broadband access driven?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Harlan, it's Eric. I'll answer the seasonality piece. Relative to broadband in Q4, it was actually a touch better than seasonal in Q4 on the strength of some key product launches in Q4. And while well within the standard deviation, a touch below the se
componenttext: So Harlan, it's Eric. I'll answer the seasonality piece. Relative to broadband in Q4, it was actually a touch better than seasonal in Q4 on the strength of some key product launches in Q4. And while well within the standard deviation, a touch below the seasonal number in Q1. So it probably nets pretty close together, but that's sort of the rough seasonal -- pretty close to seasonal when you look sort of at both quarters together.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Harlan, in terms of growth drivers, we've been benefiting from geographic expansion. We've talked about expanding into South America, into South Asia, into Africa, places like that, that have been relatively new territories for us. So that's benefited us
componenttext: Harlan, in terms of growth drivers, we've been benefiting from geographic expansion. We've talked about expanding into South America, into South Asia, into Africa, places like that, that have been relatively new territories for us. So that's benefited us certainly in 2014, and I see that continuing into the next year. As we get further into the year, we'll see more of a pickup from the 4K HEVC opportunity. That's a multiyear kind of opportunity over the next 3 or 4 years as I think a lot of the MSOs and so forth will move to 4K. And also on things like cable modem, we're seeing people move to DOCSIS 3.1. I think we'll see initial shipments this year, but that's more of a 2016 phenomenon when we'll see DOCSIS 3.1 start to really kick in. So we've got sort of a set of growth drivers there. And obviously, we'll continue to broaden that portfolio. And we've got some other businesses there, including small cells and Internet of Things and other stuff that will drive that as well.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And just a follow-up question for Eric. So on the OpEx front, and I'm certainly not complaining here, but if you can just help us understand what's driving the lower step-up in OpEx in Q1? Because typically, I think, it's about a $30 million to $40
componenttext: Great. And just a follow-up question for Eric. So on the OpEx front, and I'm certainly not complaining here, but if you can just help us understand what's driving the lower step-up in OpEx in Q1? Because typically, I think, it's about a $30 million to $40 million step-up. You're guiding it to only grow $15 million. And then I think at Analyst Day, you said you expected OpEx beyond Q1 to step up a little bit in Q2 due to more employee-related benefits and then kind of trend down Q3 and Q4. Is that how we should continue to think about it as well?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on the first point, Harlan, you're correct. So the step-up in Q1, historically, has been about $30 million to $35 million. With the reduction in the number of people associated with our exit from the cellular baseband, that number looks more like $25-i
componenttext: So on the first point, Harlan, you're correct. So the step-up in Q1, historically, has been about $30 million to $35 million. With the reduction in the number of people associated with our exit from the cellular baseband, that number looks more like $25-ish million. It was actually a pretty strong quarter in masks and prototyping costs as well, offset by solid expense management in Q1 in other areas. So that's why you see the lower number relative to what you'd expect from the step-up. We continue to expect manage our expenses pretty tightly. And going into Q1, we will continue to do so. As you look across the rest of the year, bear in mind that Q1 really has only 1 month of the merit increase in the number given the timing of when the merit increase is typically distributed. So you pick up the other 2 months in Q2. So typically, it's up a little bit in Q2 as a result of that just by itself. And then, you're right, probably flat to down in the remaining quarters of the year as the fringe comes down and we sort of manage our costs pretty tightly. The only plus or minus could be just timing of take-outs.

componenttext: Yes, sure, Ross. It's a good question. There were 2 things going on in Q1 in terms of the guide. One is that there's some mix within mix. But actually, the gross margin would actually be up slightly in Q1, but for the absorption difference between Q4 and Q1 on the lower revenue, and that's about a 25-basis-point impact. So if you use the same revenue across the quarters, we'd be looking like up 25 basis points.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: So it's just a utilization or a coverage issues that mix isn't enough to offset that I think?

componenttext: Well, no. Well, that's what's making it flat. It would otherwise be up. So there's some benefit actually that would go into Q1 if you had the same revenue. And there's some mix within mix just on timing of things. But otherwise, actually, it's slightly up in Q1 if the revenue were the same.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just as my follow-up, sticking on the expense side of the equation. I'm happy you guys are putting stock-based comp now into the numbers. I think it's a good, higher-quality number for us to look at. Can you talk a little bit about what yo
componenttext: Great. And then just as my follow-up, sticking on the expense side of the equation. I'm happy you guys are putting stock-based comp now into the numbers. I think it's a good, higher-quality number for us to look at. Can you talk a little bit about what you expect stock-based comp to do throughout this year and maybe in 2015 as a whole?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I expect in Q1 SBC, stock-based comp to be down a couple of million bucks Q4 to Q1, and then roughly flat, plus or minus a couple of things over the course of the year for the rest of the year. So the patterns that we've had in the past as we sor
componenttext: Sure. So I expect in Q1 SBC, stock-based comp to be down a couple of million bucks Q4 to Q1, and then roughly flat, plus or minus a couple of things over the course of the year for the rest of the year. So the patterns that we've had in the past as we sort of move to our adjustment in stock-based comp while seeing some of the changes, again, with less employees in the company, we should see a relatively flat stock-based comp number per quarter across the year.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Scott, on the connectivity side, can you talk about how you're feeling about your market share in the high end? And also now that most of the 802.11ac transition is done, what's going to drive the growth in this business as we look out to next 1 to 2 year
componenttext: Scott, on the connectivity side, can you talk about how you're feeling about your market share in the high end? And also now that most of the 802.11ac transition is done, what's going to drive the growth in this business as we look out to next 1 to 2 years?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'd characterize our market share in the high end of connectivity as very strong. We believe we are winning. And hopefully, we'll continue to win the majority of those designs based on very strong product execution. In terms of what drives revenue grow
componenttext: So I'd characterize our market share in the high end of connectivity as very strong. We believe we are winning. And hopefully, we'll continue to win the majority of those designs based on very strong product execution. In terms of what drives revenue growth in that area going forward, it's true that many of the customers have now moved to 802.11ac, but we see increasing numbers of diversity, antennas and stuff like that go in these boxes. So they'll move from 1x1 to 2x2 and even beyond that over time. So you can see the -- what you typically see in tablets or in laptops moves into cell phones as people look for higher connectivity performance. Also driving growth is the opportunity to add additional technologies. So for us, it's an opportunity to grow share in NFC, in wireless charging and other technologies that I think will be able to contribute meaningfully going forward.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up, you also mentioned that you have the first design win in wireless charging. Just to clarify, is that in a smartphone product? And also, how should we think about the opportunity there? Are you primarily target
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up, you also mentioned that you have the first design win in wireless charging. Just to clarify, is that in a smartphone product? And also, how should we think about the opportunity there? Are you primarily targeting smartphones? Or is the market bigger than that? And when should we expect meaningful revenue from this product?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can't share the nature of our design win there. But I mean, we expect it to be one of many going forward. We're targeting everything from smartphones to a variety of Internet of Things devices. I'm a big fan of wireless charging. It's not just a conveni
componenttext: I can't share the nature of our design win there. But I mean, we expect it to be one of many going forward. We're targeting everything from smartphones to a variety of Internet of Things devices. I'm a big fan of wireless charging. It's not just a convenience for the customer. But as many people are trying to create either a form factor change where they eliminate a lot of the USB connectors and things like that, that today are problematic both from a form factor point of view, but also from a water intrusion point of view. A lot of medical devices and even smartphones now are being characterized as water resistant to significant depths, and so sealing those hermetically is important. And so replacing all the wires, including the power connections, is very important.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question about OpEx growth going forward. You said at the Analyst Day, you thought your sort of normalized cost base growth should be about 4% a year give or take. Is that still the right number we should be thinking about? And if that's true, how shoul
componenttext: A question about OpEx growth going forward. You said at the Analyst Day, you thought your sort of normalized cost base growth should be about 4% a year give or take. Is that still the right number we should be thinking about? And if that's true, how should we be thinking about leverage in the model going forward, particularly if you start to run like more sustainably at the high end or even above your current margin target?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stacy, so you're correct, I did mention that at Analyst Day. Actually, as it turns out, we've done better than that in '14. And our hope is to continue to do better than that in '15 because we have an initiative to try to make sure that we're managin
componenttext: Yes, Stacy, so you're correct, I did mention that at Analyst Day. Actually, as it turns out, we've done better than that in '14. And our hope is to continue to do better than that in '15 because we have an initiative to try to make sure that we're managing our cost inflation down, like many other businesses do, despite the fact that the R&D costs in this industry are drifting up. To the extent that the growth rate is above that number, you should expect that there will be an opportunity to drive leverage for the P&L.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Scott, I guess my first question, I know you don't break out connectivity specifically, but is that business kind of back on a growth path year-over-year? And if you can help me understand how much of that business now is outside the handset business and kind of what the prospect is there. And then as my follow-up, FCC changed the technical definition of broadband today. I appreciate that it's early. It'll be a knee-jerk reaction. But what do you think the implications might be for your last-mile business with this change in definition?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in terms of your question, we do break out connectivity, so you can see some of that. And we'll file our K very shortly here, so you'll have the opportunity to see that. In terms of that being a growth business this year, I think it'll be challenging.
componenttext: So in terms of your question, we do break out connectivity, so you can see some of that. And we'll file our K very shortly here, so you'll have the opportunity to see that. In terms of that being a growth business this year, I think it'll be challenging. Not impossible, but it will be challenging this year simply because of some of the headwinds of exiting the baseband business. But longer term, we do see that as a growth business. In terms of the FCC thing, I haven't seen that yet, so I can't comment.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is going to come from Timothy Arcuri from Cowen and Company.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, Scott, I'm wondering if you can update us just on the connectivity buckets. You said when you exited baseband, you talked about that mid- to low-end bucket being $500 million to $800 million. And then I think you said that it's not going awa
componenttext: First of all, Scott, I'm wondering if you can update us just on the connectivity buckets. You said when you exited baseband, you talked about that mid- to low-end bucket being $500 million to $800 million. And then I think you said that it's not going away as rapidly as you thought. So I'm wondering if maybe you could update us on that and maybe what size that bucket might be in 2015. And then a question for Eric, I just want to make sure that the incremental cash flow in 2015, is it fair to assume that it's going to about 40% onshore and roughly 60% offshore?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in terms of your connectivity question, we gave a snapshot at the time we exited the cellular baseband business. And we said that we felt that roughly $100 million was at risk due to simply attach rate on our cellular baseband business, and it would de
componenttext: So in terms of your connectivity question, we gave a snapshot at the time we exited the cellular baseband business. And we said that we felt that roughly $100 million was at risk due to simply attach rate on our cellular baseband business, and it would depend who picked up that business whether we would keep the connectivity or not. And we said that there was a $500 million to $800 million total size of the business if we lost all of the small and midrange business. So that's sort of a theoretical maximum on that. I'm not going to update the size of the bucket or where we are on that going forward, but let me try to help you a little bit here. We have seen that, fortunately, a lot of the baseband business that we did lose did go to people -- partners who are friendly with us, and so we kept some of that connectivity. We're also seeing that the connectivity business is doing fairly well actually. And so with some of the baseband share shifts that are going on, and that we expect to go on over the next couple of years, we think that business is far stronger than certainly any worst-case projection and probably better than most of the sort of typical projections we would've seen. So a very good situation in the connectivity, and I see that as continuing. And I believe that will turn into a growth business for us over the course of the next couple of years.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Tim, it's Eric. Just to answer your question on cash flow. Consistent with our plan to put in place the tax strategy this year, we see the U.S. cash flow moving up from in the range of 30% to 40% to 45% of the total cash flow this year.
componenttext: And Tim, it's Eric. Just to answer your question on cash flow. Consistent with our plan to put in place the tax strategy this year, we see the U.S. cash flow moving up from in the range of 30% to 40% to 45% of the total cash flow this year.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could elaborate a little bit more on some of the trends that you're seeing within your infrastructure business. I think, Scott, you mentioned in your prepared remarks that maybe the data center business was doing a little bit better than
componenttext: I was hoping you could elaborate a little bit more on some of the trends that you're seeing within your infrastructure business. I think, Scott, you mentioned in your prepared remarks that maybe the data center business was doing a little bit better than the other buckets within infrastructure. And obviously, there's been some widely publicized weakness in the carrier CapEx, service provider piece of that end market. Maybe you can just talk about how much confidence or if you have visibility that, that carrier CapEx exposed piece is starting to bottom here in 1Q and if you can start to see some growth in that piece of the infrastructure segment as we move through 2015.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, certainly, stuff that we track. Unfortunately, we don't have a crystal ball to project the carrier OpEx or carrier capital spend that drives a lot of that business. So we're certainly tracking that there. Our goal, obviously, is to get a higher perce
componenttext: Yes, certainly, stuff that we track. Unfortunately, we don't have a crystal ball to project the carrier OpEx or carrier capital spend that drives a lot of that business. So we're certainly tracking that there. Our goal, obviously, is to get a higher percentage of the CapEx over time with broadening our product family and getting into more customers. And we do see the opportunity to expand our customer base a bit. We're in most of those customers today, but there's some we can still get as customers or broaden our footprint within them, so an opportunity there. We've definitely seen the data center as the larger driver of the growth recently. And based on the CapEx forecast I've seen, that's probably going to be certainly true in the near term. We do believe that some of the service providers, especially outside the United States, are going to increase their CapEx over the course of the year and in the years to come, so there's an opportunity there. But quite hard for us to predict there. You're probably better off getting that data from them. We'd be more reactive to that rather than able to forecast that.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess 2 quick questions. Scott, first one, is there a scenario where you could see Broadband and Connectivity flat or grow in 2015? And if so, what are the key underlying assumptions we have to make there? And then a quick question for Eric. How should
componenttext: I guess 2 quick questions. Scott, first one, is there a scenario where you could see Broadband and Connectivity flat or grow in 2015? And if so, what are the key underlying assumptions we have to make there? And then a quick question for Eric. How should we think about the strengthening dollar impacting your business, if at all?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the growth case for Broadband and Connectivity depends on how well some of our customers do and what the sell-through is for devices like high-end smartphones, where we have a very strong share in the broadband space, certainly influenced by how a
componenttext: I think the growth case for Broadband and Connectivity depends on how well some of our customers do and what the sell-through is for devices like high-end smartphones, where we have a very strong share in the broadband space, certainly influenced by how aggressively the various telcos and MSOs roll out things like 4K and really try and up the bandwidth. So that's going to be more CapEx-dependent based on those companies, whereas it's a little more consumer-dependent on the smartphones and other devices there. I think Internet of Things is going to be an important driver going forward. A little hard to predict this year. We're seeing some interesting devices come out. The watch business is an interesting business. Hard to forecast, but certainly, there's some people out there who see high forecast in that. And I think we'd certainly get a piece of that. We're in most of the watches that have been shipped to date, and we believe we can see some position in that market. But going forward, there'll be different kinds of growth drivers involved, and we'll just have to see how the year develops.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And C.J., on the currency thing, fortunately for us, on the P&L, currency has a immaterial impact to our P&L. We don't really have any sort of -- anything that sort of moves it a whole lot since we transact most of what we do in U.S. dollars. And really o
componenttext: And C.J., on the currency thing, fortunately for us, on the P&L, currency has a immaterial impact to our P&L. We don't really have any sort of -- anything that sort of moves it a whole lot since we transact most of what we do in U.S. dollars. And really our only foreign exposure, which is somewhat beneficial, is actually the cost of our employees overseas. Now when you read the 10-K, which will be published today, you'll see an OCI number. And that's really sort of a balance sheet movement of currency in places like goodwill. But again, it doesn't really impact the P&L. So we're fortunate that it's an immaterial impact to our P&L.

componenttext: When I look, though, at what's happening out in the marketplace, last night we heard from one of your old baseband competitors that they're struggling to win some feature phone business out there. Can you maybe talk if how we should think about what's going on at some of your larger customers and maybe the ramp-up and ramp-down of new projects and whether we should think that, that will impact your connectivity business?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our connectivity business has the fortunate situation of being fairly distributed over all of the larger customers and over most of the models of those customers, and so we're relatively insulated from the ramp-up or ramp-down of particular models. Obviou
componenttext: Our connectivity business has the fortunate situation of being fairly distributed over all of the larger customers and over most of the models of those customers, and so we're relatively insulated from the ramp-up or ramp-down of particular models. Obviously, if one customer were to have tremendous success with a model, that often is good for us. But share shift and ramping up models inside a customer don't have as big an impact on us because, again, of that strong market share and breadth of position across the different customers.

componenttext: Well, that's always a little hard to predict, even for us. I mean, we have some view of the different customers, but we continue to see data center is an opportunity and buildouts there. We see in broadband the geographic expansion that we've seen over the recent quarters continuing. Connectivity, we've got opportunities for new technologies. And things like NFC, things like wireless charging, I think those are opportunities for us towards the latter part this year, getting some growth there. So it will depend. We'll have to see. As we get further into the year or into next year, certainly, things like DOCSIS 3.1 and the HEVC 4K technologies are big players there as well. So we'll drive all of these different things. We also have other opportunities. Automotive still is relatively small for us, but it's a pretty good, solid, steady grower. And so over the next few years, we expect that will become increasingly material to our results and a very good business there. So it's a very broad-based portfolio. I think in the past, Broadcom was sort of dependent on 1 or 2 things for growth. And going forward here, we see quite a diversity of opportunities for growth and gives us a more balanced and diverse opportunity to have growth.

componenttext: And the follow-up is somewhat related to the way you finished that. In years past at this point, the company would often cite baseband as the priority for incremental R&D. headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: We certainly think of it at the portfolio basis, and we look at balancing R&D and putting it where it has the most benefit. I mean, what's really, I think, a blessing at this point is the bang for the buck of relatively smaller R&D investments is definitely there. One of the challenges with baseband is, it was just a very large monolithic block of investment that cast a shadow over other things. And we are now able to find a lot of projects where 10 or 30 engineers make a huge difference as opposed to thousands of engineers, like we had in the baseband space. I'm not going to share with you where we're putting our R&D bet. That's pretty confidential for us. But rest assured that we're seeing plenty of opportunity, and I think the opportunities, again, are much more tangible and we see a more certain return on those, which makes me pretty optimistic about over the next few years we should get an increase in the effectiveness of our R&D.

componenttext: I just want to follow-up on, Scott, on the 4K opportunity. The cable MSOs have been always slow to roll out new technology. It seems like over-the-top is maybe going to accelerate that. Just curious, your views on how this actually rolls out. headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think 4K is going to be something that is driven by a couple of things. I think the consumers definitely want it. And a lot of people buying, certainly, at the high-end TV sets today are going to buy 4K sets just to future proof their living room or fam
componenttext: I think 4K is going to be something that is driven by a couple of things. I think the consumers definitely want it. And a lot of people buying, certainly, at the high-end TV sets today are going to buy 4K sets just to future proof their living room or family room. I think the over-the-top guys have an opportunity to be fairly quick. But I believe the satellite guys, the cable guys, the telcos, they're all going to go on this pretty fast. And so the challenge is going to be more on the content side, I think, rather than the pure technology side because you only want to watch the nature show reruns so many times. I think sports is going to be a key driver of content. And then the movies, I think, are largely being shot in 4K today for a lot of the new movies. So you'll see that. It's amazing, the opportunities to create that. I mean, you can buy 4K drones today of very, very high quality. And so the opportunity to create content, I think, is going up. And once the content starts catching up, I think that's going to be where it'll kick over and you'll see wide-scale adoption of it because the consumers will be willing to pay incremental fees in order to get access to good quality 4K content.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: 60 gigahertz is an interesting technology. It has, because of its high frequency, the opportunity to have very high bandwidth. Yet, it also has some challenges such as, it tends to be a little more line of sight or rely on scatter and reflection. So for e
componenttext: 60 gigahertz is an interesting technology. It has, because of its high frequency, the opportunity to have very high bandwidth. Yet, it also has some challenges such as, it tends to be a little more line of sight or rely on scatter and reflection. So for example, if it's blocked by the human body, it's blocked by a table or furniture, and so it makes it difficult to use in many cases. I think you're going to see it -- the use cases are a number. I think you'll see some cable replacement where you'll replace short range cable connections, like a high-speed USB kind of connection. I think you'll see it for high-speed data backup or connectivity, where you can assure a line of sight. So those will be opportunities for it there. I don't think it will replace wireless LAN. Wireless LAN has an incredible range. We've gotten the range of wireless LAN up well over the initial 100 meter spec to 2 or 3x that, and the data rate is very higher on wireless LAN these days. So I think 60 gigahertz will tend to be specialized applications, certainly not a replacement for wireless LAN. I wouldn't be surprised you'll see devices have both in them.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Broadcom has a broad range of ARM processors that we do internally. We have ARM processors in quite a few of our devices actually, and many of them are multiprocessors. So for example, our set-top boxes have very, very strong multiprocessor ARM cores in t
componenttext: Broadcom has a broad range of ARM processors that we do internally. We have ARM processors in quite a few of our devices actually, and many of them are multiprocessors. So for example, our set-top boxes have very, very strong multiprocessor ARM cores in them. We also see an opportunity in the network space for network processors, and we've made a good effort there. And we've announced a processor architecture, which is definitely super-high performance there that competes with the highest performance processors you can get anywhere. And again, the challenge with multiprocessors is not just the speed of the processor itself, but the overall system performance because you have to balance the buses for the data and the instructions in the I/O on those devices. And so we'll look to scaling that up at the very high end in our Infrastructure & Networking space, as well as deploy it through broadband in things like set-top boxes, where you run it for applications. And then also in things like Internet of Things. We have ARM processors there where we use them for the running the applications. And those tend to be very low power, very small footprint devices. So we have probably almost 2 orders of magnitude in size of these ARM cores that we use across our whole product family.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't give you color to the extent of specific customers, but we're definitely seeing sort of the move from by 1x1 to 2x2, and we're going to see some customers go to 3x3 or other kinds of things. There's definitely an opportunity to keep upping th
componenttext: Yes, I can't give you color to the extent of specific customers, but we're definitely seeing sort of the move from by 1x1 to 2x2, and we're going to see some customers go to 3x3 or other kinds of things. There's definitely an opportunity to keep upping the performance of wireless LAN, whether it's AC in different configurations or a new AX technology going forward that has an opportunity for much better performance in crowded environments and other things. So I think that for many, many years, we see lots of opportunity to increase margin or increase competitiveness by adding additional technologies and combining them. And then of course, one of the things that Broadcom is especially good at is making all these technologies play well together. So it's one thing to have a great technology here, but it's another thing to make it work well with all the other radio technologies you have in the product. And that's a specialty of ours and works especially well in our combo chips. And so you see us broaden our combo chips to include new technologies and more advanced technologies going forward. And to your point, does that help on margin? Yes, it does, to the extent we can seal new technologies in.

componenttext: I think in the high-end switch, what you've seen from Broadcom is taking a series of high-end switches that we did in a single family, the Trident family, and now really broadening it into multiple families of high-end switches. So you see parallel product families of Tomahawk and Trident and then all of the other switches we do below that, the whole XGS family. So we've got a tremendous family there. And the nice thing is, there's great software compatibility across those, and some of our competitors like to position theirs as potentially programmable and ours not. Our switches are all programmable and customizable. So that's a misimpression that some people have gotten. We haven't seen much competition on the high end, and we've certainly seen announcements, but to my knowledge, they haven't sampled yet. So our experience is generally from the time you actually sample and get it into customers' hands, it's a year or 18 months before you see shipment and revenue on that. And I mentioned in my earlier remarks, we have something like 15 different customers who are building products based on Tomahawk today. So very, very different, I think, view of the competitors versus where we are in that space. And Broadcom has executed extremely well there.

componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thanks for joining us. Broadcom delivered strong results in the first quarter of 2015. Revenue came in at the upper end of the guided range, and non-GAAP EPS came in ahead of First Call consensus. Reportable segment revenue and operati
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thanks for joining us. Broadcom delivered strong results in the first quarter of 2015. Revenue came in at the upper end of the guided range, and non-GAAP EPS came in ahead of First Call consensus. Reportable segment revenue and operating profit grew 11% and 23% year-over-year, respectively, consistent with our objective of driving profitable growth.
Broadcom's business units are performing well. Broadband and connectivity saw double-digit percentage growth year-over-year in both revenue and operating profit and delivered revenue ahead of expectations in the March quarter. Connectivity upside was driven by successful new smartphone launches and increasing penetration of 802.11ac and to 2x2 solutions. We've now seen 2 consecutive quarters of year-over-year growth in our connectivity portfolio.
In infrastructure, year-over-year growth is being driven by world-class switch products in the data center and enterprise markets. I'll go into these items in more detail later in the call, but I'll first turn the call over to Eric for details on our first quarter results and on our second quarter guidance.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. As Peter mentioned, please refer to the data breakout in the Investors section of our breakout for additional information that will supplement my financial commentary. As a reminder, we are now including stock-based compensation in our non-
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. As Peter mentioned, please refer to the data breakout in the Investors section of our breakout for additional information that will supplement my financial commentary. As a reminder, we are now including stock-based compensation in our non-GAAP operating results in addition to allocating it to our reportable segments.
Moving to the financial overview. To summarize, Q1 came in at $2.06 billion, up 3.7% year-over-year. Excluding cellular baseband revenue, reportable segment revenue was up 11% year-over-year. Q1 non-GAAP gross margin was 54.4%, up 250 basis points year-over-year. Q1 GAAP gross margin was 52.8%.
Q1 R&D plus SG&A expense of $716 million is down over $100 million from a year ago and up $13 million from Q4. Reportable segment operating margin was 20%, up nearly 200 basis points year-over-year, consistent with our plan to drive profitable growth.
Q1 non-GAAP EPS was $0.64 per share or $0.04 above First Call consensus of $0.60 per share. Q1 GAAP EPS was $0.34 per share, which includes $0.23 of impairment charges.
Cash flow from operations used $25 million in Q1. Our cash and marketable securities balance at the end of the quarter was $5.5 billion. I will provide additional commentary on this in a moment.
Moving to revenue and gross margin. In January, we said we expected Q1 revenue of $2 billion plus or minus $75 million. We delivered revenue just below the high end of the range at $2.06 billion. Our broadband and connectivity revenue came in ahead of expectation at $1.41 billion, up 13% year-over-year. Upside was driven by wireless connectivity and broadband modems.
Our Infrastructure & Networking revenue was $631 million, up 6% year-over-year. Q1 non-GAAP gross margin was down 30 basis points from Q4 to 54.4% within our guided range of 54.7% plus or minus 75 basis points. Our Q1 GAAP gross margin was flat from Q4 at 52.8%.
Moving to operating expenses. Total R&D and SG&A expenses for Q1 were in line with our guidance.
Moving to the balance sheet and cash flow statements. Cash flow from operations used $25 million. In April 2015, we transitioned to a new enterprise resource planning system. In preparation, we intentionally took certain measures that impacted our cash flow from operations in the 3 months ended March 31, 2015, by over $400 million. We built additional inventory and paid certain liabilities earlier than we otherwise would have to help ease this transition. We expect this to reverse in the coming quarters.
Cash and marketable securities ended Q1 at $5.5 billion, of which 46% is in the U.S. During the quarter, we paid $84 million in dividends and repurchased 8 million shares of stock at the cost of roughly $350 million. As previously discussed in our 10-K regarding the construction of our new corporate campus, in Q1 we paid $156 million for the purchase of land and related prepaid assets.
Q1 accounts receivable day sales outstanding were 36 days, and net inventory turns were 6.2.
Moving to impairment of purchased intangibles. During the quarter, we recorded impairment charge of $143 million or $0.23 per share primarily related to our NetLogic acquisition. The impairment was principally driven by a reduction in size of the addressable market for merchant KBP. For further discussion of the preceding charges, please see our 10-Q that we anticipate filing today.
Moving to expectations. We currently expect net revenue in Q2 to be $2.1 billion plus or minus $75 million. Segment perspective, sequentially we expect Broadband and Connectivity to be flat to up slightly and infrastructure networking to be up. We expect Q2 non-GAAP gross margin to be roughly 56% plus or minus 75 basis points and GAAP gross margins to be about 1.5 points lower. We expect R&D and SG&A expenses in Q2 to be down roughly $15 million plus or minus $10 million.
And now I'd like to turn the call back over to Scott to talk more about the state of the business.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. Starting with our Broadband and Connectivity business, revenue came in at $1.41 billion, up 13% year-over-year and down 4.5% sequentially.Offsetting the quarter was primarily driven by wireless connectivity and broadband access. Our connec
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. Starting with our Broadband and Connectivity business, revenue came in at $1.41 billion, up 13% year-over-year and down 4.5% sequentially.
Offsetting the quarter was primarily driven by wireless connectivity and broadband access. Our connectivity business continues to strengthen. We've seen 2 sequential quarters of year-over-year revenue growth driven by consumer adoption of new high-end phones, growing penetration of new technologies such as 802.11ac and 2x2 and the ramp of new highly integrated products such as our location hub at ultra higher ASPs. We've seen significant customer interest in our latest 5G WiFi chip that offers an industry-first real simultaneous dual band or RSDB. This technology is expected to shift later this year and allows a smartphone or tablet to transfer data across 2 bands at the same time enabling new applications and increasing performance of existing applications. We also expect our new location hub product that enables always on location-based application will broaden out to more customers and phone models over the course of this year. Outside of smartphones, we're seeing a lot of activity in the Internet of Things market. We shipped a large number of wicked development kit, which are a complete hardware and software solution for prototyping IoT products.
We continue to garner new design wins in a broad set of verticals ranging across automotive, medical devices, healthcare, life goods and home automation.
In broadband, growth is being driven by pay-TV and broadband access subscriber additions, the emerging markets, technology upgrades to VDSL with vectoring and bonding and the proliferation of pond technology in China. On a year-over-year basis, combined revenue from set-top box and broadband modems were up double-digit percentages, while broadband modems actually grew sequentially versus the typical seasonal decline in Q1.
Looking forward, we see growth drivers including emerging markets, new media server architectures and new technologies such as UltraHD and HEVC. UltraHD and HEVC are still in the early adoption phase and are expected to drive growth for many years to come.
Finally, our emerging businesses of home networking and small cells are expected to be solid growth drivers as well. We're excited about the recent announcement that Cisco will be partnering up with SpiderCloud to deliver Broadcom-based small cell solutions.
Looking at Q2, we expect our Broadband and Connectivity business to be flat to up slightly sequential.
Moving to infrastructure. Revenue in our Infrastructure & Networking group came in as expected at $631 million, up 6% year-over-year and slightly up sequentially. Year-over-year growth was driven primarily by our switch and 5 [ph] products in the data center and enterprise markets.
On a sequential basis, our enterprise growth was driven by ramps and new product introductions to customers where we expect to gain market share.
Our switching business delivered record revenue and better-than-seasonal growth in the March quarter. We recently started sampling next-generation products in the StrataDNX and StrataSGX families. In the StrataDNX family, new products target data center and service provider applications and will help drive transitions from in-house -- to merchant solutions.
Broadcom introduced 8 new switch products over the past year to even further expand and strengthen our portfolio. Yesterday, we announced Trident-II plus, which is a pin-for-pin compatible upgrade to our Trident-II switch chip targeting 10- and 40-gig data center applications that offers lower power and an enhanced feature set. These products are complementary to our Tomahawk solution that targets 25-gig data center applications and which is well on its way towards production shipments later on this year.
As we look into Q2, we expect our Infrastructure and Networking business to be up sequentially.
In summary, we saw a strong start to 2015. We delivered revenue and non-GAAP EPS ahead of expectations in the first quarter and see solid trends into Q2. We saw year-on-year profitable growth in both of our reportable segments in the March quarter as Broadband and Connectivity and Infrastructure & Networking delivered operating profit ahead of revenue growth. These results reflect our business objective to deliver top line growth along with operating margin leverage. This concludes our prepared comments and now we're ready for your questions. Leslie, may we have the first question, please?

And so I think that'll give us a very strong proposition in all those markets going forward.

componenttext: Sure. So in terms of Q1 relative to Q4, I would say things came in pretty much as we had expected. componenttext: Remember that number was a theoretical worst-case number, and we want to deal it just the pain. What would happen if we lost all of the low-end mid-range in connectivity? And again as a hypothetical number, that could have happened. But what we're seeing is not only did that not happen but we're actually gaining share in that segment, and I think it's sustainable again because a lot of the partners we work with on connectivity have their own baseband are actually gaining share versus some of the baseband guys who we don't partner with, so an opportunity to gain share there. It turns out most of the people who won that business were partners with us on connectivity. So I would say that the theoretical worst-case not only did not materialize but we've grown since then as you've seen by 2 so far consecutive year-over-year increases and a likely third consecutive year-over-year increase in our connectivity business since exiting the baseband business.

componenttext: Well, on your last mission, I certainly believe and it's our goal as a company is to outgrow the markets we're in. The strength of data center, for example, hyper scale that would really pull in that ramp profile? headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of your question, I think we certainly benefit from upward trends in data center or service provider or enterprise markets. And we've seen different strengths from each of those segments. We're roughly 1/3, 1/3, 1/3 in each of those. And so it's
componenttext: In terms of your question, I think we certainly benefit from upward trends in data center or service provider or enterprise markets. And we've seen different strengths from each of those segments. We're roughly 1/3, 1/3, 1/3 in each of those. And so it's given us an opportunity there. The new products that we're announcing today, I think you for us or for our competitors or anyone else, it basically takes about a year from when you have your product in hand until the customer can shift in revenue, and then it takes a while for the revenue to ramp, and then it persists over a long period of time if you have a good ship. They don't need to replace it, they run with it for a while. And you're right, that Analyst Day slide, I think is a really good example of that. What you're seeing is both a combination of strength in the market and all the chips like Trident, the original Trident, the original Dune ships and other things are really hitting their stride now in the middle of those periods. So that gives us the strength now, and we're now putting the design wins in place with an even a broader set of products, which includes Tomahawk and the new DNX products and other things that really allow us to do that. And so that's what enables us to get record switch revenue that we saw in the quarter and above seasonal growth just with the combination of breadth of product portfolio now and several years back, all adding up and giving us the strength there. And it's a very good leading indicator for the next 5 years in that business. That should be very strong for us. In terms of M&A, we certainly look for opportunities. Broadcom sweet spot on M&A is we look to buy smaller or medium-sized near revenue or early stage revenue companies. That's our sweet spot. And we look for those when. We find good ones, we buy them. We always look at other opportunities, but we haven't been as successful buying some larger things recently that hasn't worked out as well for us, so we're probably a little bit more cautious on that than we've been in the past. But certainly to the extent we find opportunities we think really creation of our value, we'll look at those and execute to make sense.

componenttext: I think thing for the long-term growth of the business, we definitely target double-digit growth there. headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the connectivity business, I'd say our high-end business is as strong as ever. We had really competitive products there, and I think what we've been able to successfully do is to continue to drive the technology roadmap forward in that space to create
componenttext: On the connectivity business, I'd say our high-end business is as strong as ever. We had really competitive products there, and I think what we've been able to successfully do is to continue to drive the technology roadmap forward in that space to create compelling offerings for our customers. The combination of that plus a really rich product family where they can mix and match between all different kinds of combo and discrete products, adding things like sensor hub actually does make things more sticky because for example, the sensor hub is a perfect combination with GPS. And to give you an example of why that makes sense is if you think about the GPS in your phone, it has to use a fairly significant amount of power to go get a fix on the satellites and determine the location. And 1 of the things we can do integrating the sensor hubs is we can integrate the data from all the accelerometers in the phone and conclude that you're sitting on your chair, you probably haven't moved more than 5 feet and so you probably don't need to do a new GPS fix. And so by eliminating the need to do those on location calculations and not having to wake up the main baseband processor, that really saves a lot of power in the phone and it's clear win. So that allows you to, for example, combine a sensor hub with a GPS into a very effective solution, even though it's not immediately obvious that those will go well together. They do actually go very well together in terms of a better solution for the customers. So yes, I would say our high-end business is as a strong as ever. Eric, do you want to...

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the impairment -- look, our view would be if we could, do it once and call it a day. The truth of the matter is the way the accounting works is you have evaluate it every time your forecast changes in a downward direction. And in this case, as we
componenttext: Yes. On the impairment -- look, our view would be if we could, do it once and call it a day. The truth of the matter is the way the accounting works is you have evaluate it every time your forecast changes in a downward direction. And in this case, as we see more ABP functionality being integrated into switches, particularly our own, our view of the future has come down. And if the view of the future comes down, so does the overall carrying value where the present value of the cash flow which is what triggers the impairment. We don't like this drift, drift, drift either but it is a pretty formulaic way to deal with it. And I think the objective of the accounting community was to make sure that you have this visibility thing for changing. And that's principally the driver of the changes discussed in the Q that we're filing today.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: But another perspective on that is 1 of the reasons the addressable market came down is we believe a lot of the KBP functionality, at least at the low end, is getting integrated into switches. Now that's actually getting integrated into our switches, okay
componenttext: But another perspective on that is 1 of the reasons the addressable market came down is we believe a lot of the KBP functionality, at least at the low end, is getting integrated into switches. Now that's actually getting integrated into our switches, okay, so you get a benefit in our switch product and professional ASP. But the accounting doesn't allow us to transfer the value from KBP and uplift our switch business. You simply have to take the right down in the KBP business. So it's a little funny in that sense. And so just to give you a little more color on what's going on there and moving parts.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015

componenttext: I want to talk a little bit of a bigger picture thing on the foundry side. -- talked to I think a couple of analyst days ago and Henry spoke about 28-nanometer being a very long-lived node for maybe nonapplication process or type silicon. One of your customers is now ramping on since that to big volumes. I wonder how do you see the world as far as -- since that node notes and Broadcom moving down the nodes stack going forward versus the prior commentary of 28 being a long-lived node for the company?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: You know there's an expression, there are horses for courses. And there are some products that make a lot of sense on some nodes and not on others. Things like processors or big switches or fabric chips are very large chips. They are very performance-sens
componenttext: You know there's an expression, there are horses for courses. And there are some products that make a lot of sense on some nodes and not on others. Things like processors or big switches or fabric chips are very large chips. They are very performance-sensitive and they're not as price-sensitive. And so those are chips that are perfect to go to newer, smaller nodes as quickly as we can. And so you should expect that it will move our switch chips and other process-intensive switch -- intensive devices to small nodes fairly quickly. On the other hand, there are products that are either extremely cost sensitive or simply just don't get the benefit of nodes like connectivity, for example, does not benefit by moving to 60-nanometer right now because the cost equation makes that unattractive. So we believe, as Henry said, the 28-nanometer will be a very long-lived node for us. They'll be products or probably still be doing products a few years from now on that node. But then some of other more advanced products will move quickly to other nodes. We do believe we're beginning to see an end to the everything gets better, every process generation and in particular cost per transistor is 1 of the things that started to increase. And if you don't need the performance improvement or require the shrink to get better yields on your chip or something, you'll probably stay a little further back in the nodes, which I guess is good for the foundry folks because they can run their fabs longer and the depreciation equation is probably a little better for them if they can run the nodes longer. So a silver lining for our foundry partner.

Your question on the sensor hubs, I'd say we're in the early days on that, probably first inning on that and a great opportunity to go. componenttext: On Tomahawk versus Trident, we really target Tomahawk at the really high-end of cloud guys and focus on 25-gig, and that's a real advantage of that product. And so that tends to be designed into data centers going to 25 gig. Now those same customers are the ones who spearhead that movement to 25 gigs so that happens at the same time. Targeted more towards the enterprise customers or the 10- and 40-gig customers we're looking for those kind of architecture. So again really tuning those products to those specific segments. On the connectivity business in China, I'd say we're doing pretty well there. A lot of the indigenous Chinese customers are increasingly using our products in their high-end phones. We used to think of phones in China mostly as low or midrange. But if you look at the products coming out of Xiaomi or out of Huawei or Lenovo, I mean, a lot of those guys have decided they want to focus more on the high-end market and they're doing great products. And so actually, we've seen an increased opportunity in all those customers because as they look to build higher-end products or they look to also support the export market outside of China, they really want the better specs that they get from our products and the better carrier acceptance. And so that's been a very positive trend for us in China, especially at the high-end.
