Okay. Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone.  Today's call will include prepared remarks by Scott McGregor, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Eric Brandt, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
This call will include forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause Broadcom's results to differ materially and adversely from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the cautionary statements and risk factors contained in the earnings release, which was filed with the SEC today and is available on our website and in our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent reports on Form 10-Q. We undertake no obligation to revise or update publicly any forward-looking statement to reflect future events or circumstances.
Additionally, throughout this call, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Today's earnings release and the related current report on Form 8-K describe the differences between our non-GAAP and GAAP reporting and present a reconciliation between the 2 for the periods reported in the release. Please also see the Investors section of our website at investors.broadcom.com or a slide deck that includes additional information disclosed in accordance with SEC Regulation G.
Now it's my pleasure to introduce Broadcom's President and Chief Executive Officer, Scott McGregor.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thanks for joining us. Broadcom delivered strong results in the first quarter of 2015. Revenue came in at the upper end of the guided range, and non-GAAP EPS came in ahead of First Call consensus. Reportable segment revenue and operati
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thanks for joining us. Broadcom delivered strong results in the first quarter of 2015. Revenue came in at the upper end of the guided range, and non-GAAP EPS came in ahead of First Call consensus. Reportable segment revenue and operating profit grew 11% and 23% year-over-year, respectively, consistent with our objective of driving profitable growth.
Broadcom's business units are performing well. Broadband and Connectivity saw double-digit percentage growth year-over-year in both revenue and operating profit and delivered revenue ahead of expectations in the March quarter. Connectivity upside was driven by successful new smartphone launches and increasing penetration of 802.11ac and 2x2 solutions. We've now seen 2 consecutive quarters of year-over-year growth in our connectivity portfolio.
In infrastructure, year-over-year growth is being driven by our world-class switch products in the data center and enterprise markets. I'll go into these items in more detail later in the call but first turn the call over to Eric for details on our first quarter results and on our second quarter guidance.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. As Peter mentioned, please refer to the data breakout in the Investors section of our website for additional information that will supplement my financial commentary. As a reminder, we are now including stock-based compensation in our non-G
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. As Peter mentioned, please refer to the data breakout in the Investors section of our website for additional information that will supplement my financial commentary. As a reminder, we are now including stock-based compensation in our non-GAAP operating results in addition to allocating it to our reportable segments.
Moving to the financial overview. To summarize, Q1 came in at $2.06 billion, up 3.7% year-over-year. Excluding cellular baseband revenue, reportable segment revenue was up 11% year-over-year. Q1 non-GAAP gross margin was 54.4%, up 250 basis points year-over-year. Q1 GAAP gross margin was 52.8%.
Q1 R&D plus SG&A expense of $716 million is down over $100 million from a year ago and up $13 million from Q4. Reportable segment operating margin was 20%, up nearly 200 basis points year-over-year, consistent with our plan to drive profitable growth.
Q1 non-GAAP EPS was $0.64 per share or $0.04 above First Call consensus of $0.60 per share. Q1 GAAP EPS was $0.34 per share, which includes $0.23 of impairment charges.
Cash flow from operations used $25 million in Q1. Our cash and marketable securities balance at the end of the quarter was $5.5 billion. I will provide additional commentary on this in a moment.
Moving to revenue and gross margin. In January, we said we expected Q1 revenue of $2 billion plus or minus $75 million. We delivered revenue just below the high end of the range at $2.06 billion. Our Broadband and Connectivity revenue came in ahead of expectation at $1.41 billion, up 13% year-over-year. Upside was driven by wireless connectivity and broadband modems.
Our Infrastructure & Networking revenue was $631 million, up 6% year-over-year. Q1 non-GAAP gross margin was down 30 basis points from Q4 to 54.4% within our guided range of 54.7% plus or minus 75 basis points. Our Q1 GAAP gross margin was flat from Q4 at 52.8%.
Moving to operating expenses. Total R&D and SG&A expenses for Q1 were in line with our guidance.
Moving to the balance sheet and cash flow statements. Cash flow from operations used $25 million. In April 2015, we transitioned to a new enterprise resource planning system. In preparation, we intentionally took certain measures that impacted our cash flow from operations in the 3 months ended March 31, 2015, by over $400 million. We built additional inventory and paid certain liabilities earlier than we otherwise would have to help ease this transition. We expect this to reverse in the coming quarters.
Cash and marketable securities ended Q1 at $5.5 billion, of which 46% is in the U.S. During the quarter, we paid $84 million in dividends and repurchased 8 million shares of stock at a cost of roughly $350 million. As previously discussed in our 10-K regarding the construction of our new corporate campus, in Q1, we paid $156 million for the purchase of land and related prepaid assets.
Q1 accounts receivable day sales outstanding were 36 days, and net inventory turns were 6.2.
Moving to impairment of purchased intangibles. During the quarter, we recorded impairment charge of $143 million or $0.23 per share, primarily related to our NetLogic acquisition. The impairment was principally driven by a reduction in size of the addressable market for merchant KBP. For further discussion of the preceding charges, please see our 10-Q that we anticipate filing today.
Moving to expectations. We currently expect net revenue in Q2 to be $2.1 billion plus or minus $75 million. Segment perspective, sequentially, we expect Broadband and Connectivity to be flat to up slightly and Infrastructure & Networking to be up. We expect Q2 non-GAAP gross margin to be roughly 56% plus or minus 75 basis points and GAAP gross margin to be about 1.5 points lower. We expect R&D and SG&A expenses in Q2 to be down roughly $15 million plus or minus $10 million.
And now I'd like to turn the call back over to Scott to talk more about the state of the business.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. Starting with our Broadband and Connectivity business, revenue came in at $1.41 billion, up 13% year-over-year and down 4.5% sequentially. Offsetting the quarter was primarily driven by wireless connectivity and broadband access. Our conne
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. Starting with our Broadband and Connectivity business, revenue came in at $1.41 billion, up 13% year-over-year and down 4.5% sequentially. Offsetting the quarter was primarily driven by wireless connectivity and broadband access. 
Our connectivity business continues to strengthen. We've seen 2 sequential quarters of year-over-year revenue growth driven by consumer adoption of new high-end phones, growing penetration of new technologies such as 802.11ac and 2x2 and the ramp of new highly integrated products such as our location hub that all drive higher ASPs. 
We're seeing significant customer interest in our latest 5G WiFi chip that offers an industry-first Real Simultaneous Dual Band or RSDB. This technology is expected to shift later this year and allows a smartphone or a tablet to transfer data across 2 bands at the same time, enabling new applications and increasing performance of existing applications. 
We also expect our new location hub product that enables always-on location-based applications will broaden out to more customers and phone models over the course of this year. 
Outside of smartphones, we're seeing a lot of activity in the Internet of Things market. We shipped a large number of WICED development kits, which are a complete hardware and software solution for prototyping IoT products. We continue to garner new design wins in a broad set of verticals ranging across automotive, medical devices, health care, white goods and home automation.
In broadband, growth is being driven by pay-TV and broadband access subscriber additions, emerging markets, technology upgrades to VDSL with vectoring and bonding and the proliferation of PON technology in China. On a year-over-year basis, combined revenue from set-top box and broadband modems were up double-digit percentages, while broadband modems actually grew sequentially versus the typical seasonal decline in Q1.
Looking forward, we see growth drivers including emerging markets, new media server architectures and new technologies such as UltraHD and HEVC. UltraHD and HEVC are still in the early adoption phase and are expected to drive growth for many years to come.
Finally, our emerging businesses of home networking and small cells are expected to be solid growth drivers as well. We're excited about the recent announcement that Cisco will be partnering up with SpiderCloud to deliver Broadcom-based small cell solutions.
Looking at Q2, we expect our Broadband and Connectivity business to be flat to up slightly sequential.
Moving to infrastructure. Revenue in our Infrastructure & Networking group came in as expected at $631 million, up 6% year-over-year and slightly up sequentially. Year-over-year growth was driven primarily by our switch and PHY products in the data center and enterprise markets.
On a sequential basis, our enterprise growth was driven by ramps and new product introductions to customers where we expect to gain market share.
Our switching business delivered record revenue and better-than-seasonal growth in the March quarter. We recently started sampling next-generation products in the StrataDNX and StrataXGS families. 
In the StrataDNX family, new products target data center and service provider applications and will help drive transitions from in-house ASICs to merchant solutions.
Broadcom introduced 8 new switch products over the past year to even further expand and strengthen our portfolio. Yesterday, we announced Trident II plus, which is a pin-for-pin compatible upgrade to our Trident II switch chip targeting 10- and 40-gig data center applications that offers lower power and an enhanced feature set. These products are complementary to our Tomahawk solution that targets 25-gig data center applications and which is well on its way towards production shipment later this year.
As we look into Q2, we expect our Infrastructure & Networking business to be up sequentially.
In summary, we saw a strong start to 2015. We delivered revenue and non-GAAP EPS ahead of expectations in the first quarter and see solid trends into Q2. We saw year-on-year profitable growth in both of our reportable segments in the March quarter as Broadband and Connectivity and Infrastructure & Networking delivered operating profit ahead of revenue growth. These results reflect our business objective to deliver top line growth along with operating margin leverage. 
This concludes our prepared comments, and now we're ready for your questions. Leslie, may we have the first question, please?

If I assume that Broadband and Connectivity is relatively flat, your Networking business is going to grow almost 10% sequentially in Q2. I assume that most of that is data center-driven. headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015

componenttext: Harlan, I'm not sure on your number. You might want to check that. But definitely, the ING business is up, and that business is performing extremely well. We're seeing a little bit of a pause in the service provider segment, but the enterprise and data center business is definitely strong there. We've got new product introductions and quite a good pipeline of things there. So all of those contributing to drive that business and seeing a lot of strength there.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, Eric, on the OpEx front, again, another quarter of slightly lower-than-expected expenses versus the midpoint, so nice job on the discipline. You guys are guiding OpEx to step down by $15 million in Q2. Normally, we would expect an increas
componenttext: Great. And then, Eric, on the OpEx front, again, another quarter of slightly lower-than-expected expenses versus the midpoint, so nice job on the discipline. You guys are guiding OpEx to step down by $15 million in Q2. Normally, we would expect an increase for employee-related benefits and fringe. Is this just more cost and expense discipline? And then how should we expect OpEx to trend to the second half of the year?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Harlan. So good tight cost discipline on the company's part. I would say as you look into Q2, what's sort of underneath the covers is that we are managing our employee cost to be relatively flat. So we have the merit going up and the fringe coming d
componenttext: Sure, Harlan. So good tight cost discipline on the company's part. I would say as you look into Q2, what's sort of underneath the covers is that we are managing our employee cost to be relatively flat. So we have the merit going up and the fringe coming down and no additional cost. We're actually able to manage it pretty flat. What's driving that down, actually, was we had a very high mask quarter in Q1, and so it's sort of lumpy and rolled sort of up and down, so sort up, down, up, down. It's hard to predict exactly when the masks occur. So Q2 is down, maybe Q3 is back up again. But again, sort of broadly tight management on expenses. And I would say, generally speaking, my view of sort of the OpEx for the year is about what I thought it was, maybe even a little bit favorable to what I've said prior.

componenttext: I think that's a regional phenomena, Ross. We see, and we read the headlines definitely, some lower CapEx from some of the carriers in the United States. But on the other hand, we're seeing offsets by strength in China. For example, infrastructure is still continuing to go quite well there. So I'd say that's more of a regional phenomena, and we have that more balanced across our business. And it's certainly included in our guidance numbers.

componenttext: Great. And I guess as my follow-up, a quick one for you, Eric. You mentioned how there were some one-off items that made the inventory go up and the cash flow turn negative from a cash flow -- from operations perspective. Is there any color you can provide to us and how we should think about that cash generation going forward, just from a one-off basis, not about longer-term revenue guidance or anything from that?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So basically, I would expect cash flow to normalize mostly in a quarter back to what it was. So what your projections for the full year, excluding those effects, the cash flow from operations, but when you look at the cash flow statement, I'll tell y
componenttext: Yes. So basically, I would expect cash flow to normalize mostly in a quarter back to what it was. So what your projections for the full year, excluding those effects, the cash flow from operations, but when you look at the cash flow statement, I'll tell you, you can see it. You can see inventory is up about $100 million. You can see AP is up about $60 million. But if you look at what seasonally it should be, it would have been about 14 days, and that could be $140 million to $150 million, so somewhere between that. And then the other place would be other accrued liabilities where you see a very significant negative effect to the cash flow, and that's basically because we prepaid or early paid north of $200 million of rebates in the quarter. So that's where the places are, and those things should reverse themselves. Certainly, the payables and the rebates in a quarter and the inventory at least in the quarter may be a smidge longer.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess 2 questions around operating model. First off, in terms of operating margins for Broadband and Connectivity, down roughly 470 bps, and presumably, that's strength in connectivity. Curious if you could talk through how you see the trajectory for th
componenttext: I guess 2 questions around operating model. First off, in terms of operating margins for Broadband and Connectivity, down roughly 470 bps, and presumably, that's strength in connectivity. Curious if you could talk through how you see the trajectory for that line item through the year. And then as a follow-up question to that, implied guide for Q2 is basically above the midpoint of your target model for operating margins and roughly 22.5% give or take. Curious if you look at that and maybe on the mix side of Broadband and Connectivity improving, could we be hitting the 24% up margin target exiting the year? Or how should we think about that?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, C.J., it's Eric. So first of all, on the margins by business unit, the right way to look at it, because of the seasonality that's in our business, is Q1 to Q1. So if you look at Broadband and Connectivity Q1 to Q1, we're actually up year-over-year by
componenttext: Yes, C.J., it's Eric. So first of all, on the margins by business unit, the right way to look at it, because of the seasonality that's in our business, is Q1 to Q1. So if you look at Broadband and Connectivity Q1 to Q1, we're actually up year-over-year by about 230 basis points and ING infrastructure by about 140 basis points, which is what's contributing to the aggregate year-over-year of almost 200 basis points up. And that sort of gives you the sense of the leverage and the profitability of the businesses. The real sort of answer to your question is sort of what's your view of the overall market is I think we'll manage our expenses consistent with what I've said in the past and what I said just a few moments ago. And so to the extent that the revenue continues to do better than we had anticipated certainly in Q1 and given the strong guidance in Q2, I think there's additional leverage to the operating model over the course of the year. But hard to make that call since we only guide 1 quarter out.

componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll calculate an inning for that. Overall, connectivity is definitely strengthening from where we thought it was a quarter or 2 ago. And we've said that we expected that, that business would likely decline this year in the past. I would say our vie
componenttext: Yes, we'll calculate an inning for that. Overall, connectivity is definitely strengthening from where we thought it was a quarter or 2 ago. And we've said that we expected that, that business would likely decline this year in the past. I would say our view at this point is it will probably be flat or even up on a year-over-year basis. And as I mentioned, I mean, Q4 was up year-over-year, Q1 was up year-over-year, Q2, we believe, is going to be up year-over-year. That business is going quite strong. And so a lot of the concerns we had about loss of that business on exiting baseband have not materialized and we don't expect them to at this point. We see another benefit which is a number of the folks who we partner with are gaining share on the baseband space. And so that also helps our penetration and actually enables us to gain share, whereas I think a lot of people were modeling we would lose share and it's actually going the other way.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on the broadband side, Scott, I guess there is some concern in the market that because of the M&A, there could be some slowdown. I think at least one of your customers kind of mentioned that. I'm just wondering, are you seeing any impact f
componenttext: Great. And then on the broadband side, Scott, I guess there is some concern in the market that because of the M&A, there could be some slowdown. I think at least one of your customers kind of mentioned that. I'm just wondering, are you seeing any impact from all the M&A talk out there? And then if not, how should we think about some of the puts and takes in this business as we look out to the next 2 to 3 quarters?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a fair question, but it's certainly not showing up in our numbers. I mean, we have very strong broadband performance. I think it's, again, a little bit like I answered a previous question about carrier CapEx. It tends to be more of a regional thing
componenttext: That's a fair question, but it's certainly not showing up in our numbers. I mean, we have very strong broadband performance. I think it's, again, a little bit like I answered a previous question about carrier CapEx. It tends to be more of a regional thing. And so we do see a little bit of hesitation from some of the MSOs in the United States as they look at mergers. But we're seeing correspondent strength in other regions. South America and Asia and around the world, China, all of those are showing strength. I do believe that as that settles out, it will be a net positive for us because a lot of the mergers will enable those operators to really feel stronger products out there as they look to moving faster to HEVC and 4K. And so that probably gives us an opportunity to have higher ASPs in the boxes going forward. So I'd say right now, in the U.S., maybe it's a bit of a pause, offset by other regional strength, and going forward, probably a net positive.

componenttext: For the first question, I was hoping you could give us some more color on the switching market and maybe if you can provide some detail about the pace of design wins or engagements on Tomahawk relative to sort of the prior generation product launches, either qualitatively or if there's any metrics you can provide. And similarly, if you could just give us some -- an update on the market share opportunity in switching, not only with merchant chips but also if you can talk about the ASIC opportunity.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The switching business is doing really well. And I think in our StrataDNX business in particular, we've got an opportunity for -- opportunity to move to merchant silicon from some of the customer-owned ASICs, so good opportunity there. Tomahawk going real
componenttext: The switching business is doing really well. And I think in our StrataDNX business in particular, we've got an opportunity for -- opportunity to move to merchant silicon from some of the customer-owned ASICs, so good opportunity there. Tomahawk going really well. I think that's something that's sort of a must-have for customers. It's a really great product, strong specs. And it's out in the market now. We believe that customers are moving very rapidly to bring those products to market. So all in all, quite strong. Actually, I think the DNX potential is even bigger than Tomahawk. So Tomahawk, of course, is a great product, doing extremely well in the market. But I think you want to also focus on those DNX products, probably a financially bigger opportunity for us.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then for a follow-up question on the broadband business. My understanding was a lot of the opportunity around 4K TV and HEVC [ph] coding was maybe somewhat of a 2015 event but more 2016 and beyond. Just given some of the upside that yo
componenttext: That's helpful. And then for a follow-up question on the broadband business. My understanding was a lot of the opportunity around 4K TV and HEVC [ph] coding was maybe somewhat of a 2015 event but more 2016 and beyond. Just given some of the upside that you're seeing, do you think you can start to see further growth in broadband in the second half of '15 around 4K TVs and HEVC? Or is it still more of a longer-term opportunity?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's an opportunity. It will probably become more significant next year. But the key thing about that is that if you want to win a design today, you really have to have leading products with HEVC and 4K. All of the designs and decisions being made
componenttext: I think it's an opportunity. It will probably become more significant next year. But the key thing about that is that if you want to win a design today, you really have to have leading products with HEVC and 4K. All of the designs and decisions being made on what platforms and architectures are all based on your strength in that space, and Broadcom was the first there and early in that technology. And so that's enabled us to win a lot of the next generations. So those designs, a lot of them are already won, and you'll start to see those roll out over the course of time. And it's certainly good for us because it's higher ASP opportunity and also opportunity to win some customers we didn't have before. So -- especially outside of the United States, it's an opportunity for share gains. And we've talked about that as a driver for us in the past to get geographical share gain there. And certainly, the 4K transition has accelerated that.

componenttext: If I could dig into a topic that you've already touched on a little bit, and that's what's going on in the switch market, can you maybe talk to us in terms of share and how much of the market you think is converted to merchant solutions to give us some sense of what you think the runway for that business looks like as you try to push more of the market towards merchant?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think there's a tremendous opportunity to increase our share there. There's still a fair number of ASICs. And we've done a good job, I think, in terms of providing solutions that are really compelling. So we have most of the customers with at least 1 Br
componenttext: I think there's a tremendous opportunity to increase our share there. There's still a fair number of ASICs. And we've done a good job, I think, in terms of providing solutions that are really compelling. So we have most of the customers with at least 1 Broadcom solution today. But I really think there's an opportunity to show that we can really cover a broader range of switch products. And some of those customers we only have a fairly small beachhead to date. So I think we do have an opportunity for continued gains there as we go forward. And as I mentioned earlier in my remarks, I mean, we've launched 8 new switch chips this year, and I think that's a really important differentiator that isn't well understood. We have some competitors out there that talk about their switch chip, okay? And we've launched just 8 in the last year. And I think if you really want to get broad coverage in the market, the broad -- we have multiple families of devices and switches and fabrics, and it enables us to really tune those products to particular segments of the market and really create optimized products. And so I think that'll give us a very strong proposition in all those markets going forward.

componenttextpreview: I have 2 quick ones. First, around the margin trajectories. As you mentioned, you seem to be up pretty decently year-over-year. I think last year, in Q3, you were pretty darn close to 24%, which is the high end of your guidance. Given your, I guess, outlo
componenttext: I have 2 quick ones. First, around the margin trajectories. As you mentioned, you seem to be up pretty decently year-over-year. I think last year, in Q3, you were pretty darn close to 24%, which is the high end of your guidance. Given your, I guess, outlook for OpEx trajectory and growth at this point of the year, would you still expect your margins at the company level to continue to be up year-over-year as you go through the year? And then secondly, on inventories, I know you built this quarter and I understand it. Typically, inventories would be up in Q2, that would be normal. Given your views on what's going to happen with the balance sheet and the cash flow, would you expect that inventory number in Q2 at this time to be down?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Stacy, it's Eric. So first of all, on the margin trajectory. I think, really, it does depend on your view of revenue in Q3 and sort of mix of that revenue as it relates to the gross margin. So to the extent that it's a very strong consumer quarter, whi
componenttext: So Stacy, it's Eric. So first of all, on the margin trajectory. I think, really, it does depend on your view of revenue in Q3 and sort of mix of that revenue as it relates to the gross margin. So to the extent that it's a very strong consumer quarter, which it typically is, as we prebuild into the holiday season, as I said, it's a little less rich than what we currently see. So it's very much a revenue-dependent question, and I don't have any answer on the revenue for Q3 at this point because we only do one at a time. In terms of inventory targets, certainly, we would not -- we'd like our turns to move back up to where they've been before, sort of closer to 7%. So I think you can sort of build it off of that. Does that mean that the inventory goes down? It really does, sort of depend on the overall sort of cost of goods. But I think there's a chance we could have inventory moved down. Certainly, I don't think it would go up any meaningful amount, although, again, it sort of depends on how strong we expect seasonally Q3 to be.

componenttext: The headline for me is the OpEx decline here in the second quarter. And, Eric, you mentioned that mask costs were higher in Q1, but total OpEx for last quarter also came in below what I was modeling. So I was hoping you could just give us a little bit more color on what's happening with expenses. And along those lines, can you also comment on stock-based comp at $90 million? Is there additional leverage here?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So in terms of Q1 relative to Q4, I would say things came in pretty much as we had expected. We were up roughly $20 million in employee costs minus the reduction of the cellular people that left between Q4 and Q1. So in Q4, we had about 200 people l
componenttext: Sure. So in terms of Q1 relative to Q4, I would say things came in pretty much as we had expected. We were up roughly $20 million in employee costs minus the reduction of the cellular people that left between Q4 and Q1. So in Q4, we had about 200 people left, principally statutory people. And Q1, we sort of ended with about 15 people. So that knocked out about a couple of $3 million, $4 million. Stock-based compensation was favorable, as you can see from the data down about $6 million, $7 million quarter-on-quarter. And I expect stock-based compensation to be relatively flat going into Q2, pretty flattish for the year. The only wildcard on stock-based competition is we have a 2-year employee stock purchase plan, which comes up in Q4 of this year, which could have some changes to it but not significant. So that's sort of what was going on. It was a pretty strong taped-out quarter. We were up meaningfully in tape-out, so we had some offsets in Q1 from NRE which we are anticipating. But again, rolling into Q2, I expect you'll see that number come down. And probably the best way to look at it is the page that we provide in the Q or the tables we provide in the Q and look at the design development costs. They look relatively flat, but again, underneath that is pretty big tape-outs in 1 quarter, offset by some NRE, going into Q2 probably with a fair bit less on the tape-out side because, again, it's lumpy based on sort of the timing when these programs get done.

componenttext: Scott, question. It's really just big picture. How do you think about the possible impact of FX sort of on customer demand, IT spending? Do you think that we've seen the impact of that? Or do you think we're sort of yet to see the impact of that?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think we either are seeing or going to see much impact on that. We certainly have all our pricing worldwide in dollars. And so it doesn't affect us directly in terms of our own prices. I mean, the only FX we see are some of our costs that we carry
componenttext: I don't think we either are seeing or going to see much impact on that. We certainly have all our pricing worldwide in dollars. And so it doesn't affect us directly in terms of our own prices. I mean, the only FX we see are some of our costs that we carry for some of our non-U.S. teams in OpEx. But when I look at a lot of our international customers, many of our customers in Europe, for example, ship to a worldwide market. So we'll ship to a customer in Europe, and then they'll sell it to a customer in South America who's denominated in dollars. And so we're just not seeing that as a factor. I know some other companies may have cited that, but we don't see that as a significant contributor to our results so far or really much going forward.

componenttextpreview: With respect to the connectivity business, in the past, you've talked about this $500 million to $800 million of business that would decline over time -- over the long term. Is that still your view, that this long-term decline would still occur but yet it
componenttext: With respect to the connectivity business, in the past, you've talked about this $500 million to $800 million of business that would decline over time -- over the long term. Is that still your view, that this long-term decline would still occur but yet it's deferred? Or are you a bit more optimistic about that business? I understand that some of the benefit you're seeing now is a result of some customer platform decisions. I guess is long-term trajectory of that business, depending on the permanence of some of those decisions, is that the right way to think about it?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, remember that, that number was a theoretical worst-case number, and we wanted to do that just to paint what would happen if we lost all of the low-end . What would happen if we lost all of the low and mid range in connectivity? And again, as a hypot
componenttext: Well, remember that, that number was a theoretical worst-case number, and we wanted to do that just to paint what would happen if we lost all of the low-end . What would happen if we lost all of the low and mid range in connectivity? And again, as a hypothetical number, that could have happened. But what we're seeing is not only do that not happen, but we're actually gaining share in that segment. And I think it's sustainable again because a lot of the partners we work with on connectivity who have their own basebands are actually gaining share versus some of the baseband guys who we don't partner with, so an opportunity to gain share there. We did highlight that there was about $100 million worth of business that was direct attached to our baseband and that, that would depend on who won that business. It turns out most of the people who won that business were partners with us on connectivity. So instead of selling the connectivity with our own baseband, we now sell that same connectivity with a partner's baseband. So I would say that the theoretical worst-case not only do not materialize, but we've grown since then as you've seen by 2 so far consecutive year-over-year increases and a likely third consecutive year-over-year increase in our connectivity business since exiting the baseband business.

componenttextpreview: Scott, you mentioned the DNX product. Where are you in the product cycle here? When do you expect to see the volume ramps? And to what extent is this product replacing an existing Broadcom product versus penetrating the Greenfield opportunity?
componenttext: Scott, you mentioned the DNX product. Where are you in the product cycle here? When do you expect to see the volume ramps? And to what extent is this product replacing an existing Broadcom product versus penetrating the Greenfield opportunity?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we definitely have DNX products shipping today, and they're good products. And a lot of those came from our regional acquisition of Dune. And we expect that these new products will enable us to broaden the market in terms of getting more merchant si
componenttext: Well, we definitely have DNX products shipping today, and they're good products. And a lot of those came from our regional acquisition of Dune. And we expect that these new products will enable us to broaden the market in terms of getting more merchant silicon versus internal ASICs in customers. So there's an opportunity to broaden the market that way. They're also more optimized for different market segments. So it allows us to, I think, really have a more competitive product set in the switch fabric area. So those are great products. And yes, of course, the new ones replace our old ones, but at the same time, they grow the market much bigger than it was prior.

componenttext: Clarification and a big picture question. On the clarification, Eric, very strong buybacks this quarter, $335 million, but we didn't see the share count go down as much. I was just wondering if that's a timing thing. And how should we think about share count and the buyback trajectory for the rest of the year? And then the big picture question for Scott. Scott, when I look at Street expectations for Broadcom for the next 2 years, it's about 4% to 5% annual growth. I know you don't guide out more than a quarter, but is that 4% to 5% acceptable top line growth for Broadcom? Or do you think that once the baseband numbers are out, Broadcom should be able to grow in line or better than the semiconductor market, which is more like 6% to 7%?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, on your last question, I certainly believe and it's our goal as a company is to outgrow the markets we're in. We believe the best way to deliver profitable growth is to deliver faster top line than our market is growing, and that allows us to get le
componenttext: Well, on your last question, I certainly believe and it's our goal as a company is to outgrow the markets we're in. We believe the best way to deliver profitable growth is to deliver faster top line than our market is growing, and that allows us to get leverage on the bottom line. And so we want to, and for many, many years and back in Broadcom's history, we have outgrown the markets. And certainly, our compensation plans are based on that and other things. But at the same time, we want to make sure we get leverage from that growth. So it's going to depend a little bit on how the semiconductor market does as a whole, but certainly, we're motivated to do better than that. So to the extent the market does better than that, we would hope to do better as well.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And, Vivek, on your buyback trajectory, yes, you're right, the effect of the share count growing quarter-on-quarter is due to the timing of the buybacks versus the -- principally, the option exercises in Q4 and Q1. So as I said, we bought back 8 million s
componenttext: And, Vivek, on your buyback trajectory, yes, you're right, the effect of the share count growing quarter-on-quarter is due to the timing of the buybacks versus the -- principally, the option exercises in Q4 and Q1. So as I said, we bought back 8 million shares, but the buyback only registered in the quarter about 3 million, so you should see the equivalent of 5 million from the Q1 effect drop into Q2. But I would say the right way to think about this is, we committed to buyback at least double what we issue. We issued under 7 million shares in Q1, and we bought back 8 million. And we're only roughly 1/3 of the way through our buybacks. So we have more to go, and we've tried to take an advantage of doing it sooner rather than later because we have plenty of firepower to do so.

componenttext: Scott, a follow-up to Mark's question that focused on some of the new products in networking infrastructure. The answer seemed to describe the breadth -- the incremental breadth that those are providing in the marketplace. My question is more on the duration of the opportunity. If I go back to Analyst Day, Rajiv had a slide that showed that the average revenue life for his products is around 7 years, with the ramp-up going to the first 3 or 4 years. Is that way to think about these new products? Or is there something happening with the end markets now, the strength of data center, for example, hyperscaled, that would really pull in that ramp profile? And then the follow-up question would be for both you and Eric, and that is with all of the M&A activity that's continuing this year, does that cause Broadcom to think any differently about that strategy?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of your question, I think we certainly benefit from upward trends in the data center or service provider or enterprise markets. And we've seen different strengths from each of those segments. We're roughly 1/3, 1/3, 1/3 in each of those. And so i
componenttext: In terms of your question, I think we certainly benefit from upward trends in the data center or service provider or enterprise markets. And we've seen different strengths from each of those segments. We're roughly 1/3, 1/3, 1/3 in each of those. And so it's given us an opportunity there. But the new products that we're announcing today, I think for us or for our competitors or anyone else, it basically takes about a year from when you have your product in hand until the customer can shift in revenue. And then it takes a while for the revenue to ramp. And then it persists over a long period of time if you have a good chip. They don't need to replace it. They run with it for a while. And you're right, that Analyst Day slide, I think, is a really good example of that. What you're seeing is both a combination of strength in the market and all the chips, like Trident, the original Trident, the original Dune chips and other things, are really hitting their stride now in the middle of those periods. So that gives us the strength now. And we're now putting the design wins in place with an even a broader set of products, which includes Tomahawk and the new DNX products and other things that really allow us to do that. And so that's what enables us to get record switch revenue that we saw in the quarter and above seasonal growth just with a combination of breadth of product portfolio now and several years back, all adding up and giving us the strength there. And it's a very good leading indicator for the next 5 years in that business. It should be very strong for us. In terms of M&A, we certainly look for opportunities. Broadcom sweet spot on M&A is we look to buy small or medium-sized near revenue or early-stage revenue companies. That's our sweet spot. And we look for those. When we find good ones, we buy them. We always look at other opportunities. But we haven't been as successful buying some larger things recently that hasn't worked out as well for us. So we're probably a little more cautious on that than we've been in the past. But certainly, to the extent we find opportunities we think really create shareholder value, we'll look at those and execute if they make sense.

componenttext: I think for the long-term growth of the business, we definitely target double-digit growth there. I think it's harder in any current year because we're a little bit captive by the CapEx expenditure in all 3 of those segments. And there can be exogenous event such as M&A going on in their spaces or spectrum issues or government spending, all kinds of things that drive that, that we don't control. So it's a little harder to be sure what's going to happen in the next few quarters, but I think we feel pretty comfortable on a multi-year basis that, that's a double-digit grower for us.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the connectivity question, I'd say our high-end business is as strong as ever. We have really competitive products there. And I think what we've been able to successfully do is to continue to drive the technology road map forward in that space to creat
componenttext: On the connectivity question, I'd say our high-end business is as strong as ever. We have really competitive products there. And I think what we've been able to successfully do is to continue to drive the technology road map forward in that space to create compelling offerings for our customers. The combination of that, plus a really rich product family where they can mix and match between all different kinds of combo and discrete products, adding things like sensor hub, actually does make things more sticky because, for example, the sensor hub is a perfect combination with GPS. And to give you an example of why that makes sense is if you think about a GPS in your phone, it has to use a fairly significant amount of power to go get a fix on the satellites and determine a location. And one of the things we can do by integrating the sensor hubs is we can integrate the data from all the accelerometers in the phone and conclude that you're sitting on your chair, you probably haven't moved more than 5 feet and so you probably don't need to do a new GPS fix. And so by eliminating the need to do those location calculations and not having to wake up the main baseband processor, that really saves a lot of power in the phone and it's clear win. So that allows you to, for example, combine a sensor hub with a GPS into a very effective solution, even though it's not immediately obvious that those will go well together. They do actually go very well together in terms of a better solution for the customers. So yes, I would say our high-end business is as strong as ever. Eric, do you want to...

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the impairment, Ambrish, yes, look, our view would be to, if we could, do it once and call it a day. The truth of the matter is, the way the accounting rules work is you have to evaluate it every time your forecast changes in a downward direction.
componenttext: Yes, on the impairment, Ambrish, yes, look, our view would be to, if we could, do it once and call it a day. The truth of the matter is, the way the accounting rules work is you have to evaluate it every time your forecast changes in a downward direction. And in this case, as we see more KBP functionality being integrated into switches, particularly our own, our view of the future has come down. And as the view of the future comes down, so does the overall carrying value or the present value of the cash flows, which is what triggers the impairment. We don't like this drift, drift, drift either, but it is a pretty formulaic way to deal with it. And I think the objective of the accounting community was to make sure that you have this visibility as things were changing. And that's principally the driver of the changes discussed in the Q that we're filing today.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: But another perspective on that is that one of the reasons the addressable market came down is we believe a lot of the KBP functionality, at least at the low end, is getting integrated into switches. Now that's actually getting integrated into our switche
componenttext: But another perspective on that is that one of the reasons the addressable market came down is we believe a lot of the KBP functionality, at least at the low end, is getting integrated into switches. Now that's actually getting integrated into our switches, okay, so you get a benefit in our own switch product and potential ASP, okay? But the accounting doesn't allow us to transfer the value from KBP and uplift our switch business. You simply have to take the write-down in the KBP business. So it's a little funny in that sense. And so just to give you a little more color on what's going on there and the moving parts.

componenttext: Scott, I wanted to talk about a little bit of a bigger picture thing on the foundry side. I hark back to, I think, a couple of Analyst Days ago when Henry spoke about 28-nanometer being a very long-lived node for maybe non-application processor-type silicon. One of your customers is now ramping on FinFET to big volumes. I wonder how you see the world as far as the new FinFET nodes and Broadcom moving down the node stack going forward versus the prior commentary of 28 being a long-lived node for the company.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's an expression, there are horses for courses, okay, and there are some products that make a lot of sense on some nodes and not on others. Things like processors or big switches or fabric chips are very large chips. They are very performance-sensiti
componenttext: There's an expression, there are horses for courses, okay, and there are some products that make a lot of sense on some nodes and not on others. Things like processors or big switches or fabric chips are very large chips. They are very performance-sensitive, and they're not as price-sensitive. And so those are chips that are perfect to go to newer, smaller nodes as quickly as we can. And so you should expect it will move our switch chips and other process-intensive switch -- intensive devices to small nodes fairly quickly. On the other hand, there are products that are either extremely cost-sensitive or simply just don't get the benefit of the nodes. It's like connectivity, for example, does not benefit by moving to 60-nanometer right now because the cost equation makes that unattractive. So we believe, as Henry said, the 28-nanometer will be a very long-lived node for us. They'll be products -- we'll probably still be doing products a few years from now on that node. But then some of our other more advanced products will move quickly to other nodes. We do believe that we're beginning to see an end to the everything gets better, every process generation. And in particular, cost per transistor is one of the things that is starting to increase. And if you don't need the performance improvement or require the shrink to get better yields on your chip or something, you'll probably stay a little further back in the nodes, which I guess is good for the foundry folks because they can run their fabs longer and the depreciation equation is probably a little better for them if they can run the nodes longer. So a silver lining for our foundry partner.

componenttext: Two questions. First of all, on the sensor hub, is that product at just a handful of customers now? And do you expect it to be kind of a few customers each quarter added on? Or is there kind of a movement toward it that might accelerate that into -- in the second half of '15? And second question is on the infrastructure business, the data center part of it. componenttextpreview: So lumpiness in data center is definitely a factor. It makes it hard for us to predict. Now there's lumpiness in the other segments, too, but definitely, it depends. If one of our large massive data center customers is doing a huge build-out of new server
componenttext: So lumpiness in data center is definitely a factor. It makes it hard for us to predict. Now there's lumpiness in the other segments, too, but definitely, it depends. If one of our large massive data center customers is doing a huge build-out of new servers, that tends to give us a surge of orders. So it does tend to be -- there's about 10 customers who build really big data centers, and so their timing can often affect that. It makes it hard to predict. I don't think it changes the longer-term growth view of that business, but it makes it harder to predict quarter-by-quarter. Your question on the sensor hubs, I'd say we're in the early days on that, probably first inning on that and a great opportunity to go. And obviously, we'll hurry the game along and try to get a lot of runs-in on that one. But I think it's a pretty attractive product, and again, you get a lot of savings there. And I think you'll see us expand that concept and look for other ways to broaden it there. There was a question earlier about what inning are we in, in 2x2, and so I think we're roughly in the third inning on that. So a great opportunity there.

componenttext: Scott, just wanted to ask, relative position between Trident-II+ and Tomahawk. And specifically, does Tomahawk require sort of the infrastructure of 25 gigabit Ethernet to ramp before you see high volumes on Tomahawk? And then a second question on connectivity. Can you give us some sense where you see your connectivity attach rate in China? Is that still a pretty good level? Or is that sort of trended down with MediaTek and Spreadtrum mostly integrating the connectivity at this point?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: On Tomahawk versus Trident, we really target Tomahawk at the really high end of cloud guys and focused on 25 gig there, and that's the real advantage of that product. And so that tends to be designed into data centers going to 25 gig. Now those same custo
componenttext: On Tomahawk versus Trident, we really target Tomahawk at the really high end of cloud guys and focused on 25 gig there, and that's the real advantage of that product. And so that tends to be designed into data centers going to 25 gig. Now those same customers are the ones who spearhead that movement to 25 gig, so that happens at the same time. Trident targeted more towards the enterprise customers or the 10- and 40-gig customers who are looking for those kinds of architectures. So again, really tuning those products to the specific segments. On the connectivity business in China, I'd say we're doing pretty well there. A lot of the indigenous Chinese customers are increasingly using our products in their high-end phones. And you used to think of phones in China mostly as low or mid range. But if you look at the products coming out of Xiaomi or out of Huawei or Lenovo, I mean, a lot of those guys have decided they want to focus more on the high-end market, and they're doing great products. And so actually, we've seen an increased opportunity in all those customers because as they look to build higher-end products or they look to also support the export market outside of China, they really want the better specs that they get from our products and the better carrier acceptance. And so that's been a very positive trend for us in China, especially at the high end.

componenttextpreview: I think the small cell market has done well versus our expectations. I think there were some industry analysts' forecasts that were pretty far out there, and we didn't quite believe those. So if you look at it versus that, maybe so. But we've been pretty
componenttext: I think the small cell market has done well versus our expectations. I think there were some industry analysts' forecasts that were pretty far out there, and we didn't quite believe those. So if you look at it versus that, maybe so. But we've been pretty happy with small cell deployments. Broadcom has shipped over 2 million small cells to date. Broadcom is the largest shipper of small cells out there, #1 market share. And we believe that market will continue to grow. Some carriers are very excited about them. Some carriers, less so. Some carriers use them for additional coverage, and some carriers use them for more urban capacity. So there's some different business models out there that will shake out. We do see some customers that are using them alongside with set-top box or other kinds of products they deploy to utilize fairly small amounts of spectrum and create sort of a synthetic mesh net, if you will, of cellular opportunities. So we're optimistic on that business. I'm not sure I believe quite what some of the analysts were forecasting, but for us, it's a good growth business.

componenttext: So what I've heard is that both T-II+ and Tomahawk, they have support for larger routing tables, and this is going to allow the hyperscale guys to move from layer 2 switches to address layer 3 routers and stuff like end-of-row switches, basically increasing your TAM out there. componenttext: I think your basic logic is right there in terms of the applicability of our products. componenttext: There's this -- there's a competitor saying that they are programmable and we're not, and that's false, okay? Broadcom's products are programmable, too. And then, "Oh, well, are they more programmable?" And you get into these arguments. I mean, our products are programmable to the extent that our customers need. And we look to provide different ways to extend it. I mean, programmability means it takes longer to get to market because you've got more work to do. It means it can have smaller performance versus hardware assist. There are a lot of trade-offs here. So it's a really complicated equation. But rest assured that our products all are programmable and meet the needs of our market. And to the extent we need to add it, that's not very -- that's not difficult for us to do and we can certainly do that. So I think there's a little bit of a false dilemma being painted in the market there.

componenttext: Ed, so on the inventory build, I mentioned in my prepared remarks that we turned on a brand-new ERP system. So what we did was we prebuilt a lot of inventory and ordered some additional wafers under the preparation to make sure that if there are any issues with turning the system on, that we would be in a position where we could manually ship. It turns out that we turn the system on and it's operating just fine. So the inventory build was principally just an anticipation, and we had built ahead literally 1 week, 1.5 weeks of products while we made the transition. The impact to margin, there really is no impact to margin for us relative to what we're doing. It's really sort of a product now of just sort of mix and sell-through.

Okay. Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone.  Today's call will include prepared remarks by Scott McGregor, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Eric Brandt, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
This call will include forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause Broadcom's results to differ materially and adversely from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the cautionary statements and risk factors contained in the earnings release, which was filed with the SEC today and is available on our website and in our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and subsequent reports on Form 10-Q. We undertake no obligation to revise or update publicly any forward-looking statement to reflect future events or circumstances.
Additionally, throughout this call, we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Today's earnings release and the related current report on Form 8-K describe the differences between our non-GAAP and GAAP reporting and present a reconciliation between the 2 for the periods reported in the release. Please also see the Investors section of our website at investors.broadcom.com for a slide deck that includes additional information disclosed in accordance with SEC Regulation G.
Now it's my pleasure to introduce Broadcom's President and Chief Executive Officer, Scott McGregor.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thanks for joining us. Broadcom delivered strong results in the first quarter of 2015. Revenue came in at the upper end of the guided range, and non-GAAP EPS came in ahead of First Call consensus. Reportable segment revenue and operati
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thanks for joining us. Broadcom delivered strong results in the first quarter of 2015. Revenue came in at the upper end of the guided range, and non-GAAP EPS came in ahead of First Call consensus. Reportable segment revenue and operating profit grew 11% and 23% year-over-year, respectively, consistent with our objective of driving profitable growth.
Broadcom's business units are performing well. Broadband and Connectivity saw double-digit percentage growth year-over-year in both revenue and operating profit and delivered revenue ahead of expectations in the March quarter. Connectivity upside was driven by successful new smartphone launches and increasing penetration of 802.11ac and 2x2 solutions. We've now seen 2 consecutive quarters of year-over-year growth in our connectivity portfolio.
In infrastructure, year-over-year growth is being driven by our world-class switch products in the data center and enterprise markets. I'll go into these items in more detail later in the call but first turn the call over to Eric for details on our first quarter results and on our second quarter guidance.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott. As Peter mentioned, please refer to the data breakout in the Investors section of our website for additional information that will supplement my financial commentary. As a reminder, we are now including stock-based compensation in our non-G
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott. As Peter mentioned, please refer to the data breakout in the Investors section of our website for additional information that will supplement my financial commentary. As a reminder, we are now including stock-based compensation in our non-GAAP operating results in addition to allocating it to our reportable segments.
Moving to the financial overview. To summarize, Q1 came in at $2.06 billion, up 3.7% year-over-year. Excluding cellular baseband revenue, reportable segment revenue was up 11% year-over-year. Q1 non-GAAP gross margin was 54.4%, up 250 basis points year-over-year. Q1 GAAP gross margin was 52.8%.
Q1 R&D plus SG&A expense of $716 million is down over $100 million from a year ago and up $13 million from Q4. Reportable segment operating margin was 20%, up nearly 200 basis points year-over-year, consistent with our plan to drive profitable growth.
Q1 non-GAAP EPS was $0.64 per share or $0.04 above First Call consensus of $0.60 per share. Q1 GAAP EPS was $0.34 per share, which includes $0.23 of impairment charges.
Cash flow from operations used $25 million in Q1. Our cash and marketable securities balance at the end of the quarter was $5.5 billion. I will provide additional commentary on this in a moment.
Moving to revenue and gross margin. In January, we said we expected Q1 revenue of $2 billion, plus or minus $75 million. We delivered revenue just below the high end of the range at $2.06 billion. Our Broadband and Connectivity revenue came in ahead of expectation at $1.41 billion, up 13% year-over-year. Upside was driven by wireless connectivity and broadband modems.
Our Infrastructure & Networking revenue was $631 million, up 6% year-over-year. Q1 non-GAAP gross margin was down 30 basis points from Q4 to 54.4% within our guided range of 54.7%, plus or minus 75 basis points. Our Q1 GAAP gross margin was flat from Q4 at 52.8%.
Moving to operating expenses. Total R&D and SG&A expenses for Q1 were in line with our guidance.
Moving to the balance sheet and cash flow statements. Cash flow from operations used $25 million. In April 2015, we transitioned to a new enterprise resource planning system. In preparation, we intentionally took certain measures that impacted our cash flow from operations in the 3 months ended March 31, 2015, by over $400 million. We built additional inventory and paid certain liabilities earlier than we otherwise would have to help ease this transition. We expect this to reverse in the coming quarters.
Cash and marketable securities ended Q1 at $5.5 billion, of which 46% is in the U.S. During the quarter, we paid $84 million in dividends and repurchased 8 million shares of stock at a cost of roughly $350 million. As previously discussed in our 10-K regarding the construction of our new corporate campus, in Q1, we paid $156 million for the purchase of land and related prepaid assets.
Q1 accounts receivable day sales outstanding were 36 days, and net inventory turns were 6.2.
Moving to impairment of purchased intangibles. During the quarter, we recorded impairment charge of $143 million or $0.23 per share, primarily related to our NetLogic acquisition. The impairment was principally driven by a reduction in size of the addressable market for merchant KBP. For further discussion of the preceding charges, please see our 10-Q that we anticipate filing today.
Moving to expectations. We currently expect net revenue in Q2 to be $2.1 billion, plus or minus $75 million. Segment perspective, sequentially, we expect Broadband and Connectivity to be flat to up slightly and Infrastructure & Networking to be up. We expect Q2 non-GAAP gross margin to be roughly 56% plus or minus 75 basis points and GAAP gross margin to be about 1.5 points lower. We expect R&D and SG&A expenses in Q2 to be down roughly $15 million, plus or minus $10 million.
And now I'd like to turn the call back over to Scott to talk more about the state of the business.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. Starting with our Broadband and Connectivity business, revenue came in at $1.41 billion, up 13% year-over-year and down 4.5% sequentially. Offsetting the quarter was primarily driven by wireless connectivity and broadband access. Our conne
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. Starting with our Broadband and Connectivity business, revenue came in at $1.41 billion, up 13% year-over-year and down 4.5% sequentially. Offsetting the quarter was primarily driven by wireless connectivity and broadband access. 
Our connectivity business continues to strengthen. We've seen 2 sequential quarters of year-over-year revenue growth driven by consumer adoption of new high-end phones, growing penetration of new technologies such as 802.11ac and 2x2 and the ramp of new highly integrated products such as our location hub that all drive higher ASPs. 
We're seeing significant customer interest in our latest 5G WiFi chip that offers an industry-first Real Simultaneous Dual Band or RSDB. This technology is expected to ship later this year and allows a smartphone or a tablet to transfer data across 2 bands at the same time, enabling new applications and increasing performance of existing applications. 
We also expect our new location hub product that enables always-on location-based applications will broaden out to more customers and phone models over the course of this year. 
Outside of smartphones, we're seeing a lot of activity in the Internet of Things market. We shipped a large number of WICED development kits, which are a complete hardware and software solution for prototyping IoT products. We continue to garner new design wins in a broad set of verticals ranging across automotive, medical devices, health care, white goods and home automation.
In broadband, growth is being driven by pay-TV and broadband access subscriber additions in emerging markets, technology upgrades to VDSL with vectoring and bonding and the proliferation of PON technology in China. On a year-over-year basis, combined revenue from set-top box and broadband modems were up double-digit percentages, while broadband modems actually grew sequentially versus the typical seasonal decline in Q1.
Looking forward, we see growth drivers including emerging markets, new media server architectures and new technologies such as UltraHD and HEVC. UltraHD and HEVC are still in the early adoption phase and are expected to drive growth for many years to come.
Finally, our emerging businesses of home networking and small cells are expected to be solid growth drivers as well. We're excited about the recent announcement that Cisco will be partnering up with SpiderCloud to deliver Broadcom-based small cell solutions.
Looking at Q2, we expect our Broadband and Connectivity business to be flat to up slightly sequential.
Moving to infrastructure. Revenue in our Infrastructure & Networking group came in as expected at $631 million, up 6% year-over-year and slightly up sequentially. Year-over-year growth was driven primarily by our switch and PHY products in the data center and enterprise markets.
On a sequential basis, our enterprise growth was driven by ramps in new product introductions to customers where we expect to gain market share.
Our switching business delivered record revenue and better-than-seasonal growth in the March quarter. We recently started sampling next-generation products in the StrataDNX and StrataXGS families. 
In the StrataDNX family, new products target data center and service provider applications and will help drive transitions from in-house ASICs to merchant solutions.
Broadcom introduced 8 new switch products over the past year to even further expand and strengthen our portfolio. Yesterday, we announced Trident II plus, which is a pin-for-pin compatible upgrade to our Trident II switch chip targeting 10- and 40-gig data center applications that offers lower power and an enhanced feature set. These products are complementary to our Tomahawk solution that targets 25-gig data center applications and which is well on its way towards production shipments later this year.
As we look into Q2, we expect our Infrastructure & Networking business to be up sequentially.
In summary, we saw a strong start to 2015. We delivered revenue and non-GAAP EPS ahead of expectations in the first quarter and see solid trends into Q2. We saw year-on-year profitable growth in both of our reportable segments in the March quarter as Broadband and Connectivity and Infrastructure & Networking delivered operating profit ahead of revenue growth. These results reflect our business objective to deliver top line growth along with operating margin leverage. 
This concludes our prepared comments, and now we're ready for your questions. Leslie, may we have the first question, please?

componenttext: So we have a lot of opportunity to offset the normal ASP pricing pressure because of migration to new technologies. So I would say we still have quite a ways to go. We're probably in the fourth or fifth innings on just the AC conversion in general, but we have these new technologies, like the one I just mentioned, the RSDB, which again is an ASP uplift. And then we're also able to integrate additional things in there. For example, the sensor hub I mentioned, that really does a great job in terms of reducing power and other things in devices. And that's just beginning to ship in some new phones. So I think we've got a great opportunity there. And by the way, I mentioned that we've had 2 sequential quarters of year-over-year growth in connectivity. Our expectation is, in Q2, we'll probably put a third quarter of year-over-year growth in our connectivity business just to show you the kind of strength we're seeing there and it's an ongoing basis.

componenttext: Sure, Harlan. So good tight cost discipline on the company's part. I would say as you look into Q2, what's sort of underneath the covers is that we are managing our employee cost to be relatively flat. So we have the merit going up and the fringe coming down and no additional cost. We're actually able to manage it pretty flat. What's driving that down, actually, was we had a very high mask quarter in Q1, and so it's sort of lumpy and rolled sort of up and down, so sort up, down, up, down. It's hard to predict exactly when the masks occur. So Q2 is down, maybe Q3 is back up again. But again, sort of broadly tight management on expenses. And I would say, generally speaking, my view of sort of the OpEx for the year is about what I thought it was, maybe even a little bit favorable to what I've said prior.

componenttext: Yes, we'll calculate an inning for that. Overall, connectivity is definitely strengthening from where we thought it was a quarter or 2 ago. And we've said that we expected that, that business would likely decline this year in the past. I would say our view at this point is it will probably be flat or even up on a year-over-year basis. And as I mentioned, I mean, Q4 was up year-over-year, Q1 was up year-over-year, Q2, we believe, is going to be up year-over-year. That business is going quite strong. And so a lot of the concerns we had about loss of that business on exiting baseband have not materialized and we don't expect them to at this point. We see another benefit which is a number of the folks who we partner with are gaining share on the baseband space. And so that also helps our penetration and actually enables us to gain share, whereas I think a lot of people were modeling we would lose share and it's actually going the other way.

componenttext: That's a fair question, but it's certainly not showing up in our numbers. I mean, we have very strong broadband performance. I think it's, again, a little bit like I answered a previous question about carrier CapEx. It tends to be more of a regional thing. And so we do see a little bit of hesitation from some of the MSOs in the United States as they look at mergers. But we're seeing correspondent strength in other regions. South America and Asia and around the world, China, all of those are showing strength. I do believe that as that settles out, it will be a net positive for us because a lot of the mergers will enable those operators to really field stronger products out there as they look to moving faster to HEVC and 4K. And so that probably gives us an opportunity to have higher ASPs in the boxes going forward. So I'd say right now, in the U.S., maybe it's a bit of a pause, offset by other regional strength, and going forward, probably a net positive.

componenttext: The switching business is doing really well. Tomahawk going really well. I think that's something that's sort of a must-have for customers. It's a really great product, strong specs. And it's out in the market now. componenttext: That's helpful. And then for a follow-up question on the broadband business. My understanding was a lot of the opportunity around 4K TV and HEVC encoding was maybe somewhat of a 2015 event but more 2016 and beyond. Just given some of the upside that you're seeing, do you think you can start to see further growth in broadband in the second half of '15 around 4K TVs and HEVC? Or is it still more of a longer-term opportunity?

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's an opportunity. It will probably become more significant next year. But the key thing about that is that if you want to win a design today, you really have to have leading products with HEVC and 4K. All of the designs and decisions being made
componenttext: I think it's an opportunity. It will probably become more significant next year. But the key thing about that is that if you want to win a design today, you really have to have leading products with HEVC and 4K. All of the designs and decisions being made on what platforms and architectures are all based on your strength in that space, and Broadcom was the first there and early in that technology. And so that's enabled us to win a lot of the next generations. So those designs, a lot of them are already won, and you'll start to see those roll out over the course of time. And it's certainly good for us because it's higher ASP opportunity and also opportunity to win some customers we didn't have before. So -- especially outside of the United States, it's an opportunity for share gains. And we've talked about that as a driver for us in the past to get geographical share gain there. And certainly, the 4K transition has accelerated that.

headline: Broadcom Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2015

componenttext: I think there's a tremendous opportunity to increase our share there. There's still a fair number of ASICs. And we've done a good job, I think, in terms of providing solutions that are really compelling. So we have most of the customers with at least 1 Broadcom solution today. But I really think there's an opportunity to show that we can really cover a broader range of switch products. And some of those customers we only have a fairly small beachhead to date. So I think we do have an opportunity for continued gains there as we go forward. And as I mentioned earlier in my remarks, I mean, we've launched 8 new switch chips this year, and I think that's a really important differentiator that isn't well understood. We have some competitors out there that talk about their switch chip, okay? And we've launched just 8 in the last year. And I think if you really want to get broad coverage in the market, the broad -- we have multiple families of devices and switches and fabrics, and it enables us to really tune those products to particular segments of the market and really create optimized products. And so I think that'll give us a very strong proposition in all those markets going forward.

Given your views on what's going to happen with the balance sheet and the cash flow, would you expect that inventory number in Q2 at this time to be down?

componenttextpreview: So Stacy, it's Eric. So first of all, on the margin trajectory. I think, really, it does depend on your view of revenue in Q3 and sort of mix of that revenue as it relates to the gross margin. So to the extent that it's a very strong consumer quarter, whi
componenttext: So Stacy, it's Eric. So first of all, on the margin trajectory. I think, really, it does depend on your view of revenue in Q3 and sort of mix of that revenue as it relates to the gross margin. So to the extent that it's a very strong consumer quarter, which it typically is, as we prebuild into the holiday season, as I said, it's a little less rich than what we currently see.
